Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

Ahava Leibtag

\n
Ahava is passionate about content and prides herself on tackling the toughest content projects—from healthcare to higher education to hip-hop (seriously). She is the president and owner of Aha Media Group, LLC, a content strategy and content marketing consultancy founded in October 2005. Ahava has more than 15 years of experience in writing, messaging, and marketing, and is a well-recognized content expert. Her first book, The Digital Crown: Winning at Content on the Web was published by Morgan Kaufmann in November 2013
\n
\nFind me on:\n
\n \n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689818095:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSiteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n

Throughout the day, we participated in a number of workshops and sessions held by renowned international speakers, and in the evening, we competed against seven other vendors for the title of ‘Web Idol’. The competition was a lot of fun, although the pressure was on! Vendors were given only six minutes to present a case study and explain how their product had assisted in solving a web problem. Based on the American Idol structure, vendors were advised to have fun and make the audience laugh while showing off their products in a simple and informative way.

\n

Each presentation was judged on five criteria; Relevance and importance of the business problem being addressed, innovation, originality, ease of application and practicality. Competing against us were Content Management System (CMS) vendors Zengenti and Magnolia, SharePoint provider Webtop, customer management firm SDL and Software as a Service (SaaS) firm Active Standards.

\n

While the competition was tough, at the end of the day the crowd of highly experienced web professionals voted and we were crowned the winner! Our presentation was praised for its originality, and for easily highlighting how the Confederation of Danish Industry (DI) has benefited greatly from using Siteimprove Quality Assurance. With more than 10,000 members, 30 thousand plus pages and more than 250 editors that add content on a daily basis, we were able to show the audience the measurable improvement Siteimprove can offer its customers. 

As part of our attendance, we also produced a free web study that looked at the average number of misspellings, broken links, Search Engine Optimization issues and accessibility issues on 50 of last year’s participant’s websites, including Swarovski, MAN Diesel, IBM, PayPal and others.

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689823125:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWebsite Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n


Knowledge without action

\n


Talking after the conference, Jacob was satisfied with the participation from the attendees. “Our booth was very popular and I got to show many of the things that people have a hard time imagining until they have seen a review of their website made by a blind person.”

\n

According to Jacob, an increasing number of people are aware of website accessibility. “Most of the people who asked me to review their site were aware of website accessibility and knew that their site had flaws, but could not pinpoint exactly where to make improvements. They were all surprised when I went through their site with them and took a closer look at what worked and what didn’t.”  Indeed, in a survey Siteimprove carried out at the conference, 93% of web developers and managers who responded indicated they were aware of it  - yet many still don’t know how to develop an accessible website.

Jacob reports commonly experiencing problems when surfing the Internet, exemplifying that without concrete actions,  awareness of website accessibility means very little.

\n

Typical website accessibility issues

\n

Interestingly, several issues Jacob came across are much more common than others, such as missing ALT-Text Tags on images and media, applets, or other non-text web content.

\n

“It’s a huge help for me if forms are labeled and if there are heading elements, especially on larger websites. The biggest problem for me is often when there is no possibility of fast navigation, then all features of the page must be loaded, which can take forever. Preferably, everything should be able to be activated from the keyboard. The reason you cannot activate everything on the website from the keyboard is not due to technical reasons but ignorance from the web developers of the site. They are probably unaware that full web accessibility is a necessary feature for many users,” Jacob said.

\n

Web accessibility budgets and priorities

\n

“Budgets and priorities play a large role when it comes to whether a website is accessible or not,” said Jacob. While he hasn’t noted a remarkable difference in accessibility based on whether a site is public or privately owned, he has noted that perceptions to change may differ.

\n

“Private sites aren’t always willing to change if you tell them that something is inaccessible, whereas public sites often make website accessibility changes because they have a certain obligation towards all kinds of users. The budgets seem to play a bigger role for private sites as well: they are typically only driven to change things if they can make a profit.”

\n

Why website accessibility?

\n

For companies and organizations considering whether to invest in making their site handicap-accessible, it usually comes down to one question: “Will it make a difference to our bottom line?” The answer is a resounding “YES!” Often considered something that only benefits a small group of users online, making a website accessible is not only the right thing to do but also the  smart thing. Having an accessible site leads to better rankings in search engines and generally supports SEO efforts. Not a bad side effect!

While many mistakenly believe that it is both costly and difficult to develop an accessible site, it doesn’t need to be, and getting help from an accessibility expert before developing or re-designing a site is a great place to start.

\n

Download our on-demand webinar "Introduction to Web Accessibility"

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense.

\n
\n

Think about it – a university:

\n
    \n
  • Has a large population.
    • \n
  • Is highly diverse.
    • \n
  • Is geographically distributed.
    • \n
  • Has lots of stakeholders and specialist interest groups.
    • \n
\n

So, short of calling out the troops, what can you do to get everyone acting in a unified way online?

\n

 

\n

Enter ‘Web Governance’

\n

The purpose of Web Governance is to create stability in online operations.

\n

In an ideal system, all issues of ownership, authority, responsibility and resourcing are put to bed so you can focus your energies on pursuing online goals.

\n

For a small organization, this is usually quite manageable. All you need to keep the show on the road are a few informal procedures and some basic freeware tools.

\n

However, this type of informality does not scale well.

\n

For example, if the governance sophistication of a large university fails to keep pace with its online ambitions, things fall apart.

\n
    \n
  • In the absence of agreed-upon rules, solo-runs become common as individual colleges do their own thing, resulting in a wide diversity of technology and design.
    • \n
  • In the absence of skilled support, great disparities in the quality of experience emerge, as some sites are well maintained and others are ignored.
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • In the absence of necessary tools, no one can track what is happening online, exposing you to reputational risk.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

There is a way out!

\n

The answer lies in recognizing that professionalism in Web Governance must keep pace with online ambition. In the first instance, this means adopting a more sophisticated top-down model of online management. Second, it means investing in better bottom-up supports for staff, to help them maintain quality.

\n

Let’s examine both of these approaches in more detail.

\n

 

\n

Impose order from the top down

\n

A key problem on many large sites is that the complexity of operations overtakes the ability of a Web Manager to make sense of it. There are simply too many things going on.

\n

Adding to this, unlike other aspects of management (HR, finance, marketing, etc.), there is as yet little understanding of what exactly Web Governance is about.

\n

An essential first step, then, is to re-impose order on operations using a structured governance framework.

\n

Indeed, this approach can work particularly well in institutions of higher learning.

\n

Academics are used to dealing in frameworks and models, whether for physics, economics or politics. Explaining the needs and purpose of Web Governance in a similar way means you’re already speaking a language they understand.

\n

The new Framework of Web Governance describes all the elements needed to manage an online presence.

\n

The main benefit of this framework is that it reasserts order over complexity, and reveals interconnections that were once obscure by grouping similar elements together.

\n

Its second benefit is simplicity.

\n

The framework shows how everything to do with online management can be described in terms of just 3 elements. These are:

\n
    \n
  • Activity: This describes everything you must do to manage a website, no matter how big or small your site is.
    • \n
  • Resource: This describes everything you must invest in to make governance happen, e.g. people, tools, etc.
    • \n
  • Scale: This describes how to balance the Activities & Resources in a configuration of governance that works.
    • \n
\n

The simplicity of this framework makes it very effective as a communications tool when explaining what Web Governance is about to senior executives.

\n

\n

 

\n

Read a complete introduction to the New Framework of Web Governance.

\n

It is also useful for contextualizing the roles & responsibilities of everyone involved in operations. This includes the many non-web staff typically involved in day-to-day maintenance, e.g. content publishers.

\n

This brings us to our second approach for improving Web Governance: bottom-up.

\n

 

\n

Invest from the bottom up

\n

The clearest trend in Web Governance in recent years has been towards the centralization of digital activity.

\n

As noted by leading expert at Cap Gemini, Didier Bonnet: “Older Silo based operations … are coming under increasing pressure to change.”

\n

Several examples of this tendency can be seen within higher education, such as at RMIT in Australia and Harvard University, as well as in other sectors, such as government.

\n

The defining feature of this model is that nothing significant happens online without the say of the central digital unit.

\n

Well, almost nothing.

\n

Inevitably, there are instances where doing things centrally can actually inhibit progress, rather than assist it.

\n

The principle of subsidiarity states that in a highly distributed organization some activities should continue to be exercised at a local level. The challenge is allowing this to occur while still maintaining standards.

\n

This is where your new system of Web Governance must be backed-up by the supports staff need to do their jobs, e.g. online tools, process documentation, etc.

\n

In the last Siteimprove webinar, Ahava Leibtag of Aha Media Group referred to several items commonly used by content producers. The documentation and tools she described can have great utility in making subsidiarity work.

\n

The good news is that these aids can be extended far beyond publishing into other tasks of governance, e.g. quality assurance, performance monitoring, user engagement and more.

\n

Indeed, I recommend that supports of this type be packaged together into a Web Governance Toolkit for distribution among staff.

\n

\n

 

\n

For example, such a toolkit may include:

\n
    \n
  • A step-by-step guide to creating a new website.
    • \n
  • A step-by-step guide to maintaining a website.
    • \n
  • A series of documented personas.
    • \n
  • An online style guide.
    • \n
  • A series of approved KPIs.
    • \n
  • Online access to approved tools, including CMS, Analytics, QA, Social monitoring, etc.
    • \n
\n

Visit diffily.com to download free samples from a Web Governance Toolkit.

\n

This material may be collected into printed ‘packs’ and presented to staff, perhaps at the start of a major development project or as a new site goes live. This means everyone has everything they need from the word go.

\n

When done well, a toolkit can endow your Web Team with enhanced credibility and reinforce your role as a guiding authority for online.

\n

 

\n

Wait, there’s more

\n

So, we see that despite the challenges of Web Governance, there are ways to deal with it.

\n

Indeed, given the scale of the challenges, it is not surprising that some of the best solutions to online management arise within Higher Education.

\n

To learn more, be sure to tune in to my upcoming webinar on April 9th, “Top Down, Bottom Up: Two Approaches to Better Web Governance in Your University.”

\n

 

\n

Shane has more than 14 years’ experience in Web Governance & online operations. As author of the first practical guide to Web Governance (“The Website Manager’s Handbook”), Shane has also been published by A List Apart, Smartinsights & Forrester Research. For lots of FREE Web Governance downloads, visit www.diffily.com.

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n

”We can’t upload PDFs to our website because PDFs are not accessible“ and “We have to provide an accessible version of our PDFs since it is not possible to make PDFs accessible“ are both common dilemmas experienced among web teams. Perhaps these are sentences you’ve heard or even used yourself? It is a common misunderstanding…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

9. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\nMore\n
\n
\n

How to Stop Putting Out Fires and be Proactive With Your Website

\n

Everyone knows reactive marketing is ineffective, but far too many marketers are buried deep under a pile of emergencies to even think about strategic planning. What do you do when your boss comes to your desk every day to light your hair on fire with another emergency? Stop Dropping and Rolling The first step is…

\n
\n

Why Do My Documents Need To Be Accessible?

\n

Admit it: “PDFs” aren’t usually the first thing that come to mind when you think about website accessibility. They probably should be. PDFs are nearly ubiquitous as a “final” document type on the web, and hosted PDFs are often the only location certain content is made available – especially for educators, the healthcare industry, and…

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n
\n

BY Dave Schneider

\n

8. Apr 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\n

This is the second post in our series on web analytics for B2B websites, and builds on our previous post on the importance of establishing Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Micro Conversions (MCs) to make meaningful improvements to your site. Today we’ll look at how to track those interactions within a web analytics tool with Event Tracking.

\n

If the thought of tracking KPIs and MCs sounds overwhelming, rest assured: all hope is not lost. In many cases all you need is to begin tracking Events.

\n

From a strictly technical standpoint, Events are ways visitors interact with your website without going to another HTML page on your website. For example, watching a video or clicking a link to another website are both instances of events: someone clicked something, and something happened that didn’t involve loading a new page. Setting up all your KPIs as Events can be incredibly useful when it’s time to report your analytical findings to leadership.

\n

Many people are unaware that this functionality is present in any analytics tool worth using. Siteimprove Analytics, Google Analytics, WebTrends, et all have the ability to track Events. Therefore, when evaluating tools for your organization it’s important to ask, “how are Events set up so I can effectively measure success on my website?” There is an opportunity for a whole separate post here on how to decide between free and paid tools, but for the sake of brevity I’ll limit my thoughts on that topic to a few sentences:

\n

Free tools and paid tools both cost money in different ways. If you are willing and able to pay with your time to learn the free tools, then you should use free tools. If you are unwilling and/or unable to pay with your time to learn the free tools then you should purchase a tool. There will always be a certain amount of work involved in effectively analyzing a website, and that time commitment grows if you decide to go the free route.

\n

Once you’ve decided what kind of tool is right for you, it’s time to get Event tracking set up! In most cases Events require a “Category,” “Action,” and “Label” so you can easily distinguish between different Events. It’s up to you (or you and your analytics provider) to determine the appropriate naming conventions for your Events. This is critical, as it will affect how you are able to use the data in your analysis. Due to the importance of this task I would like to look at each item on its own.

\n

 

\n

Category

\n

The first part in naming an Event is placing it in a category. Video can be a category that encompasses all video on a website. Links can be a category for your Events that happen to be links. Audio can work for podcasts, etc. It’s best not to get too creative with your categories and just stick with common sense. The only reason to get creative is if you need to distinguish some sub-categories in order to better analyze your information.

\n

Here’s a quick example:

\n

Let’s say I’m a manufacturing company that builds different kinds of widgets based on two different types of customers, Mikes and Ikes. I have some PDF documents that outline the specifications of my widgets, and when those documents are downloaded that tells me there is an interest in potentially purchasing my widgets.  If the only category I had was “Documents” then I may need to do some extra analysis every time I needed to recommend website updates to my leadership. What I could do instead is have one category called “Mike Documents” and another called “Ike Documents.” Then I can look at my conversions at a glance based on the type of customer downloading the specs allowing me to determine a course of action with less effort.

\n

If you’re just getting started with this and don’t have access to a consultant, it might be wise to stick to more basic categories. If there is a case to be made for sub-categories, then go for it.

\n

 

\n

Action

\n

Actions are very self-explanatory. This is the action that a user takes on an Event. For a video it could be “play,” for a link it could be “click,” for a document it could be “download.” We don’t need to get into much detail on these. Just call a spade a spade and you’ll be fine.

\n

 

\n

Label

\n

The Label element is often the name of the Event being interacted with. The title of an individual document is a good label, the name of a video will work. This is another area that does not require much depth, just common sense. You simply need to be able to recognize individual Events within your categories and the Label is the way to do so.

\n

Once you have settled on the naming conventions for all your Events, you then need to follow the appropriate steps for your Analytics tool of choice in order to track them. If you’re a Siteimprove Analytics customer, that step is to contact our support team, who will guide you through the entire process. Otherwise, consult your tool’s support options and get down to brass tacks.

\n

You will then begin collecting the glorious information on how often people are taking action on your KPIs and MCs. This is progress! It is also just the second step in our journey, and there’s so much more value ahead. In our next installment we’ll take a look at the value of making Campaign Tracking a part of your outbound marketing efforts.

\n

Want more best practices for measuring your website’s success? Check out our report on the eight most deadly web analytics mistakes:

\n

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Top-Down, Bottom-up: 2 Approaches to Better Web Governance at Your University

\n

I have heard it said that if a university was a country, it would last about a week before breaking apart in civil war. At first brush it sounded ridiculous, but now I think it actually makes a good bit of sense. Think about it – a university: Has a large population. Is highly diverse….

\n
\n

\n

Say goodbye to inaccessible PDFs on your website

\n\n\n\n\n\n 8689822655:\n\n\n\n\n\nA Web Governance Framework That Works\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n

    • \n

\n

\nA Web Governance Framework That Works\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n\n
\n

This article was reprinted with permission from Shane Diffily, Web Governance Consultant and author of The Website Manager's Handbook.

\n

Web Governance (also known as Website Governance) is the discipline that describes how to manage a website in a controlled and orderly way.

\n

Until quite recently few online professionals were much interested in Web Governance. There were too many other problems that needed fixing first, like poor design and content.

\n

But not anymore.

\n

A new generation of executives for whom the web is neither cool nor cryptic are lifting the lid on operations and discovering teams that are badly structured and under-resourced.

\n

To set things right they need a practical framework upon which to build a revised system of Web Governance.

\n

In this article we’ll explore a new model that explains in clear language how Web Governance works and a first step towards changing it for the better.

\n

A new system of Web Governance
At its most basic Web Governance can be defined in terms of just 3 components:

\n

• Governance Activities - These describe everything you must do to manage a website effectively.

\n

• Governance Resources - These describe everything you must have to support the above activities.

\n

• Website Scale - This concept determines how to configure the above Activities & Resources into a workable system of Governance.

\n

Continue Reading…

\n

Shane Diffily, “A Web Governance Framework that works!” Diffily.com, November 2012 http://www.diffily.com/articles/model.htm

\n

\n \n \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 8718700905:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n

\n

\nWeb analytics: gathering qualitative and quantitative data \n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/11/12 5:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In basic terms, most web analysis systems are based on quantitative data. This quantitative data contributes to general knowledge about the usage of a given website. Everything can then be broken down into numbers and graphs to be interpreted by the person responsible for the optimization of the website.

\n
\n\n
\n

Since the person who interprets the data often has a thorough knowledge of their website, the result will most likely be marked by this. This is natural enough and in most cases it also makes the person interpret the data better. However, in-depth knowledge of the website can also be a hindrance and make you blind to general poor functionality that harms the user experience.

\n

Let the users put it into words

\n

One of the obvious possibilities to get around this interpretation problem is to collect qualitative user data where the user has the opportunity to comment on how they see the user experience.

There are many obvious methods in which you can give users this option. It can be anything from user interviews and sample groups to best user feedback. These methods give the user the ability to verbalize their experience, which can help contribute to an interpretation closer to reality.

When developing new websites, it is a perfectly natural thing to ask users to be involved in user tests or similar. Since you haven't got the quantitative data yet; this is only available from users when your website goes live.

\n

It might be a good idea to pursue the philosophy that lies behind user testing during the design phase. Just because a website "goes live" doesn't mean that it's fully developed. Developing a website is an ongoing process where you constantly have to keep up with how people use it. This knowledge should then be used to constantly strive to improve the user experience.

\n

This exercise is to improve the user experience on your website, and the data you can get, quantitative or qualitative is ultimately beneficial.

\n

Use data for what it is good for

\n

It's important remembering to use the data collected for what it is good for. The quantitative data contributes with large amounts of general knowledge that show a bigger picture of how  mass users use your website. However the qualitative data, that comes directly formulated from the users themselves, contributes with very specific knowledge about specific areas, and information you may never have even thought of.

Each type of data has its own strengths and weaknesses, but the combination of both provides the analysis tool with an extra dimension that can make the interpretation of your data even sharper, and even closer to reality.

The approach to web analytics should be to learn to know your users better, and get as close to reality as possible. In this way you can get in the best position to optimize your website so as thereby to improve the experience users get when they visit. Therefore, it is also important to hear what users have to say in words, and not least allow them to share their experience in an easily accessible manner.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Involving People With Disabilities In Your Web Project

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n11/4/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Involving people with disabilities on your web projects may seem like an overwhelming task, but if you do, it will be well worth your effort. The benefits will far outweigh the extra work, as you'll be gaining a much deeper understanding of how users with disabilities are motivated, how efficient your site may be, and how effectively all of your users can be while using your site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

Web Editors: Create Accessible Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Applying Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n1/23/13 2:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

It may be one thing to write blog posts about Web Governance, but using it in your day-to-day work is a completely different ball game. In this blog post I’ll show how we’ve tried to apply Web Governance at Siteimprove, and hopefully you’ll learn from our challenges.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting Started With Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/9/13 10:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In this post, you'll find a brief walkthrough of how to begin using the basic features of an analytics program. We will be using Siteimprove Analytics as our example, however the suggestions made should carry over to any program.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n

Web Developers: Create an Accessible Website

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\nSiteimprove Announces US Relocation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n

“The new office opens new doors for Siteimprove,” said Torben Rytt, CEO. “Our recent expansion paves the way for new hires, which means the ability to pursue new and existing markets, improve customer service, and strengthen organizational infrastructure. Siteimprove staff and services are growing quickly, and our new location will help to sustain that growth.” 

\n

The new 11,000 square foot office doubles the 5,500 square foot space Siteimprove previously held in Uptown, Minneapolis, and adds flexibility for further expansion with additional available space nearby.

\n

The additional space was put to use immediately, as Siteimprove welcomed several new employees within the first week after finishing the move to the new office. New positions are consistently available on the Siteimprove Careers page.

\n

“The new space eases congestion and has simplified the process of on boarding several key additions to our team. Because of this, Siteimprove customers can continue to expect the same top-notch customer service and attention to detail they’ve always enjoyed despite the rapid growth of our customer base.” said Rytt.

\n

Since 2003, Siteimprove has provided industry leading Web Governance tools to thousands of organizations worldwide. Headquartered in Copenhagen, Denmark with offices in Minneapolis and London, Siteimprove has a strong presence in dozens of countries across North America, Europe, and the Middle East. Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite, offered via Software as a Service [SaaS], helps organizations manage and maintain their large websites through web quality assurance, web accessibility, web analytics, SEO analysis and web performance alerts.

\n
\n
\n
\n

\nWeb Developers: Create an Accessible Website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/2/13 2:35 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you developing your website for many types of users, or are you primarily developing for people who access websites in much the same way as you do? Do you know how dyslexic users, people who are colorblind, people with impairments and others navigate the web?

\n
\n\n
\n

This week's blog post is the second in a three-part series covering websites and accessibility with a role-based approach for Web designers, web developers and web editors. This contribution is meant for web developers. The previous was intended for web designers and the final is meant for web editors. In each post, I give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n

Include the remaining 20% of users

\n

Surveys show that up to 20% of web users are affected by accessibility issues when surfing the web. By following the principles of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines you ensure that as many people as possible can use a website. In the following paragraphs I will give tips on which criteria are relevant for you as a web designer.

\n

Page titles

\n

Make sure that all web pages have a descriptive title reflecting the page content. Also make sure that web editors can enter page titles via the authoring tool (for example CMS).

\n

Keyboard navigation

\n

All content on a web page should be navigable both with a computer mouse and from the keyboard alone. This applies to forms, buttons and links for instance.

\n

Some users are not able to use a computer mouse. They can use the keyboard only to navigate by tabbing through content on a web page. These users need to be able to see where they are located on the page. For this reason it should always be visually evident where on the web page the tab indicator is located. Most browsers automatically show this with a dotted line around the content. You can also implement your own way of showing this.

\n

Content sequence

\n

When content for web pages is coded make sure that the content, not only visually but also in the coding sequence, has a meaningful order. Some users navigate pages by this order. Ensure that the order of content is sensible when styles are disabled and when tabbing through content.

\n

Enlarging

\n

Make sure web page text can be resized up to 200% as a minimum, and still be usable and look sensible (newer browsers can zoom content and this is usually the way that assistive technologies do it as well).

\n

Language

\n

In order for user agents to be able to render content in the correct language, it is important that the pages have a correct language definition in the HTML tag for a web page. The language tag should be 'en' for English pages for instance and 'da' for Danish pages and so on.

\n

Also the CMS should give web editors the ability to highlight text that is in a different language than the rest of the page. The highlighting should add the lang="" attribute into the code.

\n

Coding

\n

In order to make sure that the website is shown consistently across different platforms (such as operating systems and browsers) and ensure technologies can render content in a meaningful way, the standard for the format one publishes in should be complied with. If, for instance, you are publishing in XHTML 1.0 or HTML 5.0 the syntax rules for this format should be followed. You can check your web pages for syntax errors at: http://validator.w3.org/.

\n

Also make sure that elements are marked up with the correct tags. For example, HTML headings should be tagged as <h1></h1> (h1…h6).

\n

Data tables should be tagged as <table> and web editors should be able to add descriptions to data tables via <caption>. Headings for columns and rows should be defined by the use of <th> and perhaps 'header id' and 'scope'. If a complex data table needs explaining for screen reader users, then this should be done via 'summary'.

\n

When writing text, web editors should be able to emphasize with <strong> and <em>.

\n

When form elements are used, a label should be explicitly connected to each control and form elements that belong to the same group should be assembled. For instance a group of radio buttons should be grouped with<fieldset> and <legend>. There are a number of techniques to ensure this: Techniques for 1.3.1 and Techniques for 4.1.2.

\n

User input

\n

If the user is to enter information in a text field, make sure that where the user does not enter text in the right format the user is notified with text, and if possible help the user correct the mistake. When filling out a form that is part of a financial transaction or a legal commitment where data is changed, the input must be checked by the system to avoid errors or the user should have the option of reading through the input before sending it. A third option is that the user can always reverse the submission.

\n

Graphics

\n

When web pages contain elements that are non-textual it is important to give a textual alternative describing the purpose of the non-text element. This for instance can be an image. For images the HTML attribute for alt text is used (alt=""). It is important to note that the alternative text reflects the purpose of the image and not necessarily what the image is of. The authoring tool (such as a CMS) should allow for entering alternative texts on images that are displayed on web pages. The alt attribute should always be tagged on all images, and should allow the web editor either to leave the field empty or give a description for an image. An alternative text is context specific, so it can be poor accessibility practice to enter a single alternative text for every instance of a specific image when uploading to the media library. Your authoring tool should allow you to enter a new alternative text every time an image is used on a web page.

\n

If a web page contains a media file, it should also be given a descriptive text either as an alt attribute or in the object tag on inline elements and the like.

\n

Audio and video

\n

When you publish audio and video on a web page, give an alternative format and add captions and audio description.

\n

Make sure that all buttons and navigation in the video player can be used both with a computer mouse and with the keyboard alone. Give all the buttons and navigation text descriptions to help screen readers.

\n

For a video you should be able to enter a dedicated track for audio description and also the option to add captions.  If a passage of audio starts automatically, the user should be able to pause, stop, or control the sound volume.

\n

User control

\n

Some users need a long time to read and navigate web pages. Therefore, if some sort of time limit is present on pages, such as a time out, the user must be able to change the limit either by adjusting it, extending, or disabling it.

\n

If content for moving, blinking or scrolling is added, it is also important that the user can pause, stop or hide this content.

\n

In order for screen reader users to avoid having to listen to the same content every time they load a new page, provide the option of skipping blocks of repeated content. Repeated content can be a global menu (and local menu) and help functions. There are several techniques for ensuring this. The easiest way is to provide a link at the top of all pages that takes the user to the main content of the page (for instance the heading 1 on the page in the content section). There are other options as well: Techniques for 2.4.1.

\n

When an element is to be altered by the user, such as a drop down menu, a radio button or the like, it is important that it acts as the user expects. Elements should not react solely from receiving focus or when the user lands on it from the keyboard. It should react when the user has had the time to choose and confirm.

\n

Blinking content

\n

In terms of the above, specifically for blinking content, this should not happen with a frequency of more than three times a second, otherwise it may cause an epileptic episode for some users.

\n

If you would like to know what web designers and web editors should focus on, you can read my whitepaper  'How to ensure website accessibility'.

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Mike Waterston

\n
\n

Recent Posts

\n
\n
\n

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Redesign Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/11/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website redesign. Those two simple words are enough to make even the most seasoned of marketers break out into a cold sweat. Research, planning, meetings, debates, design, user experience, content, development, approvals, and that’s just the process for deciding whether or not you should do a redesign. The sheer amount of work needed to pull off a website redesign is often all it takes to make companies reconsider the whole idea, but it doesn’t have to be.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

4 Tips For A Fall Website Cleanup

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/7/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Clutter is OK on your desk. Sure, your co-workers will be silently (or not so silently) judging you as stacks of paper, coffee cups, and assorted knick-knacks pile up around your keyboard like garbage in a landfill, but it’s part of your process, right?

\n

Your website, on the other hand, is no place for clutter. Customers expect simple navigation, easy to find information, and useful content. If your website took the summer off to relax, it’s time to put it back to work.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

A Web Governance Framework That Works

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

    • \n
  • \nOctober 2012 (5)\n

A Look at Assistive Technology

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n4/15/14 10:37 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Assistive technologies are tools and methods used to make web information available to people with and without disabilities. With the leaps and bounds in technology the last few years, you may not be aware of all of the different kinds of Assistive Technology available.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility,\nAssistive Technologies\n

\n
\n
\n
\nAll posts\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Do a Winter Checkup on Your Internal Search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n12/27/12 2:43 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

With holidays and winter weather approaching, it’s time to make sure that your internal search engine is ready for specific winter topics.

\n
\n
\n

Winter search topics

\n

You might think that "Christmas" and "snow" are the typical topics to optimize for, and it does make sense to make sure that the most relevant pages of your website come up at the top of your searches for these terms. However, the search terms that are being searched for most often during the holiday season are related to opening hours.

\n

In most organizations, opening hours change during holidays, and we typically see a spike in searches for hours of operation during December and January. Users also search for information about services that may have a change in schedule, like garbage collection.

\n

Preparing for search term synonyms

\n

Forgetting to optimize for synonyms of relevant words is a common mistake. Make sure that you catch all versions of the search terms being used. If you're working to optimize searches for garbage collection, appropriate synonyms of 'garbage' might include:

\n
    \n
  • Trash
    • \n
  • Refuse
    • \n
  • Waste
    • \n
  • Bin
    • \n
  • Recycling
    • \n
  • Collection
    • \n
\n

Additionally, opening hours during the holiday period should be searchable for all offices in your organization. If your organization provides services such as a library or a swimming pool then make sure that opening hours for these amenities during the holiday period are searchable too.

\n

Recycle search term statistics from last winter

\n

If you're looking to find specific search terms to optimize your internal search for, I recommend checking your analytics from last year. By looking at which search terms were searched for in December/January last year, you'll get a good idea for where to start this year.

\n

Share your experiences with us!

\n

Do you check and update your internal search?  We'd love to hear your experiences in the comments below. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/24/12 3:42 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n

Carefully Selected Content: Website Redesign Tips From a Search Perspective

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n10/3/12 4:05 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The Siteimprove series on maximizing the potential of a website redesign continues with today's post on the internal search function. We'll take a look at ideas on how your internal search can be used as a helping tool in the general design and testing of your website, as well as guidance on how to best design your search page.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Dive into search statistics

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

3 Things you can do to improve your internal search

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n4/11/12 11:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

You may think you don’t need to do that? After all, you can find content without doing so. It is essential that you use the internal search regularly. Your search page transforms and looks different depending on which search term you use. Users on your website might view a search result page that you have never seen yourself.

\n
\n

Your search function might be in perfect shape, and not need any adjustments at all. If not, it is time to take control of your internal search function. Since the search function uses the content of the pages on your site the process mostly starts with improving the most important pages.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

Five Common Web Design Mistakes to Avoid

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n7/30/13 2:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Despite the web having been around for over two decades design mistakes are still increasingly prevalent. Below we list five simple, but common, mistakes to avoid when designing a website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Hierarchy of Content Needs: A New Model for Creating and Assessing Content

\n

\nPosted by\nHilary Marsh\n

\n

\n7/9/13 10:53 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Hilary Marsh Psychologist Abraham Maslow developed a theory of human motivation that he called the hierarchy of needs. As explained in the Economist, “Needs in the lower categories have to be satisfied before needs in the higher ones can act as motivators. Thus a violinist who is starving cannot be motivated to play Mozart, and a shop worker without a lunch break is less productive in the afternoon than one who has had a break.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Putting a Face on Accessibility Part II

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n7/1/13 10:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Professor Chris Olson has had a really busy year. Chris recently bought and moved into a house. Like many home purchases, there was a bit of remodeling that took place before the move to make the space more usable. Chris will be sharing that new home with his fiancé Cindy. Chris and Cindy were engaged on New Year’s Eve. Chris has been teaching graduate and undergraduate level computer and web programming classes for the past seven years. In March 2013, he successfully defended his doctoral dissertation, “Awareness of Accessibility in Computer-based Instructional Materials and Faculty Demographics in South Dakota Public Universities.”

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n
