Who are Siteimprove Employees?

\n

A multinational company, with more than 100 committed employees in 5 countries, who are proud to work together to make Siteimprove the world leading provider of web governance tools and solutions to more than 30,000 web professionals.
\nMeet the Minneapolis Office.

\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Torben
    Rytt

    \n

    Chief Executive Officer - Siteimprove, Inc.

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Torben
    Rytt

    \n

    Chief Executive Officer - Siteimprove, Inc.

    \n
    \n

    As CEO of Siteimprove, I am responsible for leading the Northern American office by motivating our staff, cultivating strategic partnerships, overseeing all aspects of sales and marketing, and maximizing the company’s ROI. When Siteimprove entered the American market in 2007 we accounted for less than 3 percent of Siteimprove’s worldwide revenue. Today, we’re proud to make up more than 58 percent!

    \n

    Before joining Siteimprove, I worked extensively within the computer and software industries in a variety of director roles, from project management, to sales, and chief operations. I work hard to grow our business and to earn the respect of my staff and peers, because without them we would not have been able to achieve such continued success.

    \n

    I co-founded my first business while still going to school in Denmark. Since then, I have worked my way through the professional ranks and was eager to accept the challenge of building the Siteimprove brand here in North America.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Roger
    Fuhrman

    \n

    Vice President of Sales and Marketing

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Roger
    Fuhrman

    \n

    Vice President of Sales and Marketing

    \n
    \n

    At Siteimprove, I’m responsible for leading the sales and marketing teams, optimizing processes for increased efficiency, and mentoring a team of more than 25 talented sales professionals.

    \n

    Before joining Siteimprove, I worked extensively within the technology and software industries for almost two decades. Whether in a director role, inside and overlay sales, or customer relations, I always try to imbue my work with an enthusiastic and energetic style, and dedicated approach to building relationships and solving problems.

    \n

    Fun Fact:  The reason I am an avid St Louis Rams fan is because when I was in the 2nd grade, I liked a girl that was in the 4th grade.  When I asked her what her favorite football team was, I was told the Rams.  Been following them ever since!

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Steve
    Hennigs

    \n

    Vice President of Customer Success

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Steve
    Hennigs

    \n

    Vice President of Customer Success

    \n
    \n

    I really enjoy the Siteimprove atmosphere and culture. Everyone here is hard working and dedicated. The unique challenges faced by our customers and how we can help solve them make it exciting to come to work each day. It’s been amazing to grow with this company as one of its first 3 employees to over 50!

    \n

    I enjoy spending time outside with my wife and our dog, golfing, paddle boarding, reading, and lately- yoga.

    \n

    Fun Fact: I used to sing professionally as a chorus member in the Minnesota Opera.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Joe
    McNeill

    \n

    Director of Sales

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Joe
    McNeill

    \n

    Director of Sales

    \n
    \n

    I love working with a team to create synergy between an individual’s personal goals and the company’s goals. I really look forward to working more with this extremely talented team, assisting individuals in reaching their personal goals, helping customers better manage their web content, and helping us blow our growth goals out of the water time and time again!

    \n

    Prior to Siteimprove, I managed the Business Development group at Proto Labs. My team was in charge of all new business acquisition and we were able to accomplish a lot in my ~4 years there. We helped grow Proto Labs’ revenue by roughly 290% and we increased our sales team from a headcount of 12 to close to 75. Through it all, my proudest achievements include having Proto Labs voted a top 100 workplace in MN four years straight, and also being named the 3rd best small business in America by Forbes in 2013 and 2014. I see a lot of similarities with Siteimprove’s culture and growth trajectory and I’m excited to go through it all again.

    \n

    Outside of the office, I love Hockey, Pheasant/Duck Hunting, and spending time with my family and pooch.

    \n

    Fun Fact: My wife is a professional dance teacher, yet I remain a terrible dancer.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Heather
    Orfe

    \n

    Technical Support and Training Manager

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Heather
    Orfe

    \n

    Technical Support and Training Manager

    \n
    \n

    Before joining Siteimprove, I worked extensively within in a variety of web focused communications roles, starting out interning for companies such as Winona Health and Mayo Clinic before moving up to positions as Web Communications Assistant and Contract Marketing Coordinator.

    \n

    I started my career at Siteimprove within the technical support department where I demonstrated my passion for customer relations and effective training methods. Now, as the Siteimprove Technical Support and Training Manager, I play a key role in training and educating clients, and ensuring Siteimprove’s ongoing success.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Melanie
    Elliott

    \n

    Finance Manager

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Melanie
    Elliott

    \n

    Finance Manager

    \n
    \n

    As the Finance Manager, my tasks span widely at Siteimprove- including implementing our awesome accounting process, overseeing contracts and purchasing, as well as general office management. Mostly, I try to create positive changes and make our office a fun, open, and comfortable environment for all of our employees.

    \n

    I have many proud moments at Siteimprove and these moments include knowing I play a valuable role in guiding employees in their success and adapting to changings to ensure a successful growth in our company.

    \n

    When I’m not making this place more awesome, I’m out paddle boarding, watching movies, going to wine tastings, and pretty much anything that doesn’t involve a computer.

    \n

    Fun Fact: I hiked the Tom, Dick, and Harry trail in Portland, OR, and the Crater Lake trail that reached 8,929 ft. http://www.portlandhikersfieldguide.org/wiki/Tom_Dick_and_Harry_Mountain_Hike

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Kristin
    Troup

    \n

    Human Resources Manager

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Kristin
    Troup

    \n

    Human Resources Manager

    \n
    \n

    Prior to joining Siteimprove I worked in a variety of positions within Human Resources, ranging in size from small start-ups to large multi-national companies.

    \n

    In my role as Human Resources Manager at Siteimprove I look forward to building upon the dynamic culture, and streamlining processes and procedures in order to prepare us for the future.

    \n

    In my spare time I enjoy spending time with my family, walking and biking.

    \n

    Fun fact:  I have yet to find a dessert that I don’t like

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Betsy
    Johnson

    \n

    Talent Acquisition

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Betsy
    Johnson

    \n

    Talent Acquisition

    \n
    \n

    I’m the first point of contact to showcase Siteimprove as the best place to work in North America and the UK. I also spearhead the new hire onboarding program which, has now been implemented at all of Siteimprove’s global locations.

    \n

    When I’m not helping Siteimprove find the best talent worldwide, you can find me eating my way through every foodie hot spot!

    \n

    Fun Fact: I’m the reigning Super Bowl Office Pool Champion.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Laura
    Greschner

    \n

    Accounts Receivable Specialist

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Laura
    Greschner

    \n

    Accounts Receivable Specialist

    \n
    \n

    I keep the Siteimprove checkbook in order along with providing general office entertainment to those within my vicinity. Before joining the team at Siteimprove, I worked for a local B2B company where I handled accounts payable and receivables, as well as data entry.

    \n

    When I’m not in the office, you can find me enjoying a cold beer on a disc golf course, singing karaoke, working on my beach body at the gym, or road tripping across the country.

    \n

    Fun fact: I have a moderate to severe obsession with Sriracha sauce, and may or may not, but definitely may purchase it in bulk.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Jennifer
    Anderson

    \n

    Accounts Receivable Specialist

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Jennifer
    Anderson

    \n

    Accounts Receivable Specialist

    \n
    \n

    We’re a diverse group of people who skills are more than just an asset, we’re a well-oiled machine that finds the finish line every time! Working in the accounting area can be challenging at times but working in such an upbeat atmosphere allows me to be successful both professionally and personally. There’s never a dull moment around here and the fun-loving environment is contagious!

    \n

    When not at the office, you can typically find me running around with my children. They keep me very active whether it be on the soccer fields or playing a game of Yahtzee. When it’s time for just me, a nice glass of wine and some time with good friends sharing some laughter is a must!

    \n

    Fun Fact: I’ve parasailed on a frozen lake. Yep. Strap 300 yards of rope to the back of a truck, throw on some motor cross gear, a helmet, downhill skies and add in the parasail!  Floating 100 yards above a frozen lake behind a truck will give you a whole new perspective on the fun things you can do during a Minnesota winter!  Just watch out for the landing.  Did I mention I hate heights?

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n

    \n

    Fun Fact: I worked at Starbucks, but I hated coffee. Then after leaving Starbucks, I saw the light.

    Kevin
    Rydberg

    \n

    Senior eAccessibility Consultant | Email: Kry@siteimprove.com

    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n    \n
    \n
    \n
    \n

    Kevin
    Rydberg

    \n

    Senior eAccessibility Consultant | Email: Kry@siteimprove.com

    \n
    \n

    My role at Siteimprove has put me in a unique position where I’m able to help people by teaching them, both online and in person. I enjoy interacting with coworkers and customers, and showing people the need and benefits of accessible web programming. For over ten years I have actively contributed to a better Web through my work in accessibility, usability, and design. I have held varying roles from web strategist, consultant, project manager, and editor. I designed and deployed the Siteimprove Web Accessibility Certification Program and enjoy speaking at various Tech/Web industry conferences. I also work closely with customers on specific issues on their websites.

    \n

    I like getting together with friends and family, bargain hunting at thrift stores, and attending my kids’ sporting and academic events. My son participates in both baseball and football, and my daughter is very involved with academic activities. We also host a lot of barbecues. Speaking of…

    \n

    Fun Fact: I make my own barbecue; you can find me most weekends with some form of critter prepared, rubbed, and sitting in my smoker while I patiently (not always patiently) wait for a proper smoke ring. My barbecue has been known to make native Texans tear up—in a good way!

    \n

    Memberships & Associations

    \n
      \n
    • Section 508 Accessibility Professionals
      • \n
    • Sioux Falls Young Professionals Network
      • \n
    • UWEBD – University Web Developers
      • \n

      • \n
    • W3C Web Standards
      • \n
    • Society for Technical Communications
      • \n
    • Sigma Tau Delta International English Honor Society
      • \n
    • Dakota State University Alumni
      • \n
    \n

I’m also the person who uses the awesome Siteimprove tool to work on the quality assurance, SEO, accessibility and analytics of our own website. Working for a company with such great people means I have a lot of positive energy to bounce off of.

    \n

    I enjoy coming up with creative ways to highlight and promote our incredible product, and since the Siteimprove tool is something I personally use as a web developer, it allows me to have a much deeper understanding of how it can benefit our customers.

    \n

    I’ve worked on marketing teams for over 10 years, so I’m able to bring ideas from strategy and concept, all the way through to final production. Two tradeshow booths that I designed graphics & videos for even won Best of Show awards at shows with over 1,500 exhibitors.

    \n

    Outside of work, I find inspiration from movies, live music, and most of all being a Dad…sharing experiences of the modern world with a child can be fascinating and hilarious.

    \n
    \n

    Working with educators and public school systems is incredibly rewarding. The Siteimprove product is such a revolutionary tool, and most of the time customers don’t even know this technology exists, so I love getting to see and hear their reactions when they see what our product can do.

    \n

    Within the first four months of being promoted into a sales role at my previous job I was able to double the licensed sales revenue each month, and accounted for almost 20% of sales on my eight person team.

    \n

    Outside of work, I enjoy staying active by playing in various football, basketball, softball, and volleyball leagues.

    \n

    Luke

    \n

    Account Executive - Higher Education

    \n
    \n

    I consider myself incredibly fortunate to work for a company like Siteimprove. Having the opportunity to build relationships with educators while working alongside great people is a real privilege. Every college I work with is different, so I enjoy the challenge of identifying what makes each one tick, and finding a way to personalize our services to their needs. What I love most about my job is having those “ah- ha” moments, and seeing people’s reactions when they realize just how much our tool can help them.

    \n

    Outside of work you can find me spending time with my friends and family, or doing something active. Whether it’s playing basketball, golf, swimming, or running, I try to take full advantage of the few months a year where it’s possible to go outside in Minnesota. I’m also an avid traveler, and try to keep checking various countries off my list.

    \n

    Fun Fact: I can moonwalk, but that’s where the similarities between Michael Jackson and myself end.

    Maria
    Vaughan

    \n

    Account Specialist - Education

    \n
    \n

    The best part about my job is when customers have their “Ah-ha Moment”, and discover how much our product can really improve their website, and save them valuable time.

    \n

    Before working at Siteimprove I worked for a medical supply company where I managed the 2nd largest nursing home chain in the US.

    \n

    Outside of work you can find me exploring Minneapolis with my friends, golfing with my family, or training for my next half marathon.

    \n

    Fun Fact: I have zero cavities, I am probably close to being legally blind without my contacts, and I broke my arm in 5th grade and 6 weeks after I got the cast off I broke it again.

    \n
    \n

    \n

    I have a fine art degree, but don’t get to practice it much, because I’m out enjoying time with my kid, gardening, cooking, and hanging out with my family.

Also, the work culture at Siteimprove is fantastic, everyone is very welcoming and fun loving, but they also know how to roll up their sleeves and get the job done.

    \n

    I started my first business while in college at Saint John’s University and named it Johnnie Fitness. The personal training and health consulting business continues to thrive even though I have passed it on to a successor.

    \n

    Outside the halls of Siteimprove, I enjoy being with friends, playing and watching sports, biking, running, being outdoors, writing my three part trilogy book, reading, eating and cooking, trying craft beers and wines, travelling to new places, or pretty much anything that is new and exciting.

    \n

    Fun Fact: I was voted “Friendliest Guy” at my high school and believe it is one of my greatest accomplishments in life thus far.

Why You Might Want To Rethink That Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n1/6/15 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Redesigning your website and expecting all of your problems to disappear is like buying a new house because you’re too lazy to clean the one you live in now. Oh, it'll look nice for a while, but eventually you’ll be up to your armpits in clutter again. The same goes for your website. Slapping on a fresh coat of paint might make it look shiny and sleek, but the fundamental problems will remain below the surface.

\n

Spending time, money, and energy on driving traffic to a broken website is a massive waste of resources. Users might be flooding your site, but if all they find are broken links, poor navigation, a lack of direction, and accessibility issues, the frustrating experience will turn them off for good.

\n

The good news? These are all issues that can be addressed on your existing site. So, what can you do instead?

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nWeb Governance,\nContent,\nWebsite Redesign,\nWeb Design\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Can SEO Benefit Brick & Mortar Banks?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/18/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Online banking is awesome. Everyone knows that. Checking balances, paying bills, transferring money, even depositing checks; online banking has made it easy for people to manage their basic finances from the comfort of their home computer or mobile device.

\n

But what about more complicated financial activities like applying for home and auto loans, planning for retirement, savings investments, or managing small business expenses? The average person will have questions. They’ll need information on how to start planning and who to trust with their money. And where does the average person begin their search for answers? That’s right, online.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Content, Your Audience, and Search Engines

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/28/14 10:03 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Quality over quantity, right? “But wait”, you say. “I thought that adding more content and blogs would help boost my site’s SEO rankings?” Well, yes and no. Simply cramming your website full of unfocused, aimless ramblings is actually a sure fire way to earn the ire of both your readers and that company whose name rhymes with “Moogle”. It’s Google. I’m talking about Google.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n10/6/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO. What’s that idiom about birds and stones? 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website SEO Checklist

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n9/9/14 10:05 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What Google says, goes. They are the Alpha and Omega when it comes to online search, and their search algorithm is what dictates how your website’s SEO needs to be calibrated. In order to receive the maximum return on your online investment, your website’s SEO needs to cross off a number of key to-do’s before it can reap the rewards from Skynet Google.

\n

If you haven’t been keeping up with Google’s latest algorithm updates, read our blog that discussed the evolving SEO landscape. Go ahead and read it, I’ll wait.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How The Evolving SEO Landscape Is Impacting Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/20/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Search engine algorithms are getting smarter; Google in particular. Until recently, cramming your webpages with keywords and outbound links was enough to trick them into thinking that your website was relevant to the search terms. As more and more people began to “game” the system, Google got wise and decided to change the game. Get up to speed on the new rules.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n

How to figure out which How-To’s to write

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n3/17/13 3:01 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

How-To’s are great. They provide answers to your customers’ questions, but they're also a great opportunity to get some relevant targeted content on your website and boost your SEO efforts. But how do you know which How-To’s to write?

\n
\nRead More\n

Simple, yet lethal SEO no-no's

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n2/19/13 3:07 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

“A website is like an island resort. It serves no purpose if no one can find it” Dr. Clinton Cimring, Trademarker of the acronym S.E.O

\n
\n
\n

While most of us focus a lot of our time and money on improving our SEO, it's often the basics that are our undoing. With that in mind, we've come up with a list of common elementary mistakes that people make time and time again. And remember if your SEO efforts still aren't paying off then it may be time to consider investing in an SEO tool that helps take the mystery out of it.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

\n

\nDive into search statistics\n

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n6/6/12 10:54 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Search statistics are not only essential for evaluating and maintaining the search function on your website, they are also useful for many other purposes. It is a free opportunity to learn about what your users expect from your website. Do you have the information users need? Is it well organized, and is it easy to click though to the pages that are most sought after?

\n
\n\n
\n

Direct input from your users

\n

When users submit a search term, they are fundamentally telling you that they have a specific information need which they expect to be answered by your website. Search terms are a direct and clear indication that information on a topic needs to be on your website and it needs to be easy to navigate to. In other words: taking a look at your search statistics helps you improve the user experience on your website based on data!

\n

Get inspiration - compare search statistics to your front page.

\n

By comparing the most frequently searched search terms to the terms on your front page you can get inspiration for both content and layout.

\n

If a term is sought after by many users, the information is not accessible enough. There might be no link at all to the information on the front page, or it might be hidden behind a term that users don't associate with their information need.   Some users might not be able to find the library page if it is only accessible under a link with the text "Leisure."  Check whether a link to information that is in your top search results is properly linked to, with a link that is clearly visible under the scroll-line or in a banner.

\n

To summarize: your search statistics often contain words that are not found via links from the front page or the top navigation. It might indicate that your information architecture is not answering user needs well enough.

\n

Dive deeper - do you have the content that users expect to find?

\n

Is there content on your website about the topics that users searched most for?

\n

Three good statistics that you can use to find the items you need to add content addressing are:

\n
    \n
  1. Search terms with no result.
    2. \n
  2. Searches where users moved on to page two of their result list.
    3. \n
  3. Searches where users left the site after seeing the search result.
    4. \n
\n

If possible, also check the search terms that have been searched for more than five times and identify categories of searches that did not give satisfying results. Categories might be searches for employee names, abbreviations and technical terms.

\n

Once you have determined the topics where the users expect information that is not on your website, decide whether you want to integrate website content about these topics, or whether you want to set up a page that explains that the information is out of the scope of the site with a link to the authoritative source for the topic. For example, there may be many searches for employees in your organization, so you might want to improve the information offered to the employees in your organization.

\n

If there are many searches for content that are located in separate searches, such as employee data, consider integrating the information in the general search. Alternatively, include a reference to the right place to search for personal data.

\n

Search statistics also provide insight into the language people use to find what they are looking for. Do they use abbreviations, outdated words or specific technical terms? Consider replicating your user's choice of wording in the text on your website, or make sure that the internal search finds relevant results, by applying various synonyms to key words.

\n

If you want to get more specific tips for working with search statistics, I recommend the book "Search Statistics for Your Site" by Louis Rosenfeld. It is an easy read and gives hands-on advice for working with search statistics. You can also keep an eye on the blog here, where I will continue to write about internal search and search statistics. 

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9028100535:\n\n\n\n\n\nWebsite Benchmarking Study: Local Government\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

Website Benchmarking Study: Local Government

Mistakes are costly.

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Your website is your residents' primary source of information, and usability errors like broken links and misspellings destroy credibility. When searching for resources like city maps, community calendars, and voting information, broken links prevent them from accessing the content they need, and misspellings prevent them from utilizing your search functions effectively.

\n

This study provides benchmarking for local government website quality standards.

\n
\n

Issues examined in this study:

\n
\nBroken links
Misspellings




\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n© 2015 Siteimprove Inc\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Life Sciences

\n

Health and wellness is serious business for you and your clients. They look to you to provide them with answers to their questions and guidance for the future, but that can’t happen if your website is confusing or doesn’t provide the right information. Let us help you maintain a healthy website.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Life Science

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website errors that are preventing your clients from finding the information they need most, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to provide the most helpful information in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Happy clients

\n

Here's what they have to say about us

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    Every company with a large website should use Quality Assurance from Siteimprove. Nowadays, your website is your brick and mortar, so reputable content and accurate information is key to any brand. Siteimprove will streamline the process and easily point out any errors or inconsistencies.

    \n
    \nInternet Specialist at Saint Joseph Mercy Health System
    \n
    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We've seen a 56% increase in average time spent on our website. Quality Assurance makes finding and fixing problem areas on our site much more manageable - we couldn't maintain our site so responsibly without it.

    \n
    \nLead Web Developer at BOSCH Security Systems

\n

Insurance

\n

Accidents happen, and we’re not talking about your clients, we’re talking about your website. Broken links, misspellings, and slow performance can be frustrating roadblocks for your clients when they need your help the most. We’ll help protect your website, so you can worry about protecting your clients.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Insurance

\n

With Siteimprove, your team will be able to identify potential website errors that are preventing your clients from finding the information they need most, such as: broken links, misspellings, and accessibility concerns. We’ll also help you optimize your content for search engines and analyze how pages are performing, which will allow you to provide the most helpful information in the future.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check website accessibility issues WCAG 2.0

    \n

    Issues and Guidelines in Siteimprove Accessibility checks and identifies the WCAG 2.0 success criteria conformance levels A, AA and AAA for ensuring accessible web content. For instance, missing text alternatives, such as success criteria 1.1.1 Non-text Content which affects screen readers accessing images and even search engine performance. Siteimprove Accessibility also helps list and prioritize errors, flags warnings and allows you to review and ignore WGAG 2.0 issues accordingly.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Check online PDF document accessibility errors

    \n

    As well as scanning web pages for WCAG 2.0 accessibility issues Siteimprove Accessibility also scans all of your site’s PDFs for detectable issues as part of WCAG 2.0 / ISO 14289-1:2012 / Matterhorn Protocol. This includes full document and single page element accessibility issues affecting usability, from missing headings and bookmarks to images without alternative text.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

    \nMarketing Director at Senn Delaney Leadership Consulting Group, LLC.

    \n
    \n

\n

Manufacturing

\n

Streamline your website marketing processes and minimize content errors with Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite. Our tool audits your website for broken links and misspellings, Search Engine Optimization (SEO)-damaging issues, WCAG 2.0 compliance issues, and create automated workflows delegating the workload across your team – all integrated with an analytics tool so simple you’ll actually use it.

\nRequest a Demo\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove for Manufacturing

\n

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite, offered via Software as a Service [SaaS], helps manufacturing organizations manage and maintain their websites through web quality assurance, web accessibility, web analytics, SEO analysis and web performance alerts.

\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n

    Stress-free Language Management

    \n

    Easily see every spelling mistake on your website, and utilize the powerful dictionary editing features to eliminate false positives and proactively flag inappropriate words. Plus if you were to accidentally add a misspelled word to the dictionary it’s no problem as all changes can be reviewed and edited.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Quickly Identify Broken Links

    \n

    Siteimprove’s crawlers check every link on every single page of your site so that you don’t have to. With options to filter broken links by internal and external, you can quickly see where the problem lies. Plus run reports at any time to instantly see your progress.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Manage keywords and page optimization relationships

    \n

    Siteimprove SEO Keywords helps monitor your website’s target keywords on their corresponding pages and indicates average Google rankings so you can effectively optimize page by page. Additionally, Page Analyses functionality helps provide meaningful keyword score data, based on content SEO issues, ranking, visits from search engines and bounce rate. Plus this data also provides useful keyword suggestions taken from organic search results, so you can determine which keywords you should be optimizing for using Siteimprove SEO.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Access to Complete Inventory

    \n

    Get a comprehensive overview of media files, PDFs, and other documents across multiple websites. Find every instance of sensitive details like email addresses, phone numbers and social security numbers, plus utilize our simple diagrams which show which sites contain what media files, email addresses, and more.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n

    Schedule and Customize Reports

    \n

    Siteimprove Quality Assurance custom reports are delivered directly to your inbox, with prioritized error lists directing your attention to where it’s needed most. Plus generate, schedule and customize unlimited report templates to suit you or your staff’s needs.

    \n
    \n
    \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

\n
\n
    \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    \nExpert Technical Assistance

    \n
    • \n
  • \n
    \n\n
    \n

    We've seen a 56% increase in average time spent on our website. Quality Assurance makes finding and fixing problem areas on our site much more manageable - we couldn't maintain our site so responsibly without it.

    \n\n
    \n

    We love Siteimprove Response! It revealed that our internet service was at 92-93% uptime, rather than our service provider’s 99% guarantee. We were able to take the data from Response and present it to our Internet Service Provider, who then dramatically improved our service.

    \n
    \nSystems Analyst at Tampa International Airport

\n

The Story.

\n

For more than 10 years Siteimprove has been providing organizations of all shapes and sizes with web governance tools and solutions, and we are happy to share our major milestones with you.

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\n
    \n\nEarly 2000's\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Figuratively speaking that is. While working as a consultant for a public Danish company, Morten was asked to check a website for broken links and he quickly realized there was a serious gap in the market for a group of diagnostic tools that could take the hassle out of performing tasks manually. Starting out with just himself and a couple of programmers it wasn't long before a baby was born.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\n2003\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Born in central Copenhagen during a warm October of 2003, Siteimprove wasn't always an easy baby, although it proved early on in its infancy that it had a talent for setting itself apart from the crowd. Intelligent and intuitive it quickly found itself at the front of the class when it came to quality checking tools. Counting many of Denmark's best-known companies and institutions, such as Sydbank and the Danish Defense Intelligence Unit among its friends, the future seemed bright.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\n2004\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Looking to spread its wings and test its universal appeal Siteimprove travels to London. Taking quite a liking to a nice lager and beans on toast, it decides to leave its mark and before leaving Siteimprove Ltd. UK is established.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\n2007\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Well and truly bitten by the travel bug Siteimprove's next big trip is a visit to the good old U. S. of A. Enjoying the sites it ventures further into the market before finally settling on an office in Minneapolis. A gamble that pays off. Today the North American market accounts for around 80% of all Siteimprove's business.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\n2008\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Not content to rest on its laurels, Siteimprove continues to enjoy its travels, and after a visit to Scandinavia’s most populous country decides to set up shop.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\n2012\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Deciding no trip was complete without a good place to call home for a Bratwurst and Pringle, Siteimprove expands into Europe’s strongest economy – the German market.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n\nPresent\n\n
    \n
    \n

    Since its birth into humble beginnings, Siteimprove has only grown and improved. With offices in 5 countries, and a client base of more than 3000 websites and over 30,000 web editors in the public and private sectors, it truly is one of the world’s leading suppliers of web governance tools. Siteimprove looks forward to getting to know you.

    \n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n

Latest news.

\n

Your one stop spot for all the latest news about what we’ve been up to, what we plan on doing, plus plenty of extra exciting announcements about everything from web governance news, customer visits, partnerships, sponsorship’s, awards and much more.

Siteimprove Releases New Trademark Monitoring Feature for Web Governance Suite

\n
\n

BY Star Bazella

\n

2. Oct 2014

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, Siteimprove launched a new feature within their Web Governance Suite that enables users to monitor for consistent Trademark usage. This new feature allows users to ensure that names, copyrights, and trademarks are presented accurately according to organizational standards.

\n

Protecting intellectual property is essential in today’s constantly evolving digital marketplace, yet many organizations lack the resources to maintain constant vigilance of their trademarks across a large online presence.

\n

Siteimprove customers will now have access to a specific Trademark section within the web governance dashboard that lists all instances of trademark symbols (©, ®, ™) across their website, allowing users to identify any incorrect uses of these important brand elements.

\n

The new trademark monitoring feature helps you:

\n

\n
    \n
  • Ensure consistent presentation of organizational trademarks
    • \n
  • Locate errors, duplicates, and inconsistencies
    • \n
  • Monitor for names, products, and services that should never be displayed without a trademark
    • \n
\n

The Trademarks feature is designed as an extension of Siteimprove’s Content Policy feature, which allows website managers to flag unwanted content while monitoring for content consistency across their entire website.

\n

”It can be difficult to ensure that all of your trademarks are displayed correctly on your website – especially if you have a lot of them,” said Kate Sygrove, Project Manager at Siteimprove. “Siteimprove’s Trademark feature ensures that you will be able to not only locate inconsistencies, but to fix them quickly and easy.”

\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

Siteimprove Promotes From Within, Names New VP of Customer Success

\n

Software as a service (SaaS) company, Siteimprove, has named Steve Hennigs as their new Vice President of Customer Success. Hennigs has been with Siteimprove since opening their U.S. office in 2007 and previously occupied the role of Senior Product Specialist. Hennigs will be heading up the newly created Customer Success Team, which will aim to…

\n\n\n\n\n\n 9089757615:\n\n\n\n\n\nCase Study: University of Ontario Institute of Technology\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

University of Ontario Institute of Technology

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Thank you for requesting our case study

\n
Click here to download the case study


This case study gives a brief explanation of how University of Ontario Institute of Technology uses Siteimprove to overcome AODA (Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act) issues commonly faced by Canadian college web teams.

\n

Like to learn more? Click to Request a Demo

\nManaging websites can be tricky, especially the more pages it has, and the more people responsible for its content.

Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite helps organizations manage and maintain their websites through:
\n
    \n
  • Web Quality Assurance
    • \n
  • Web Accessibility
    • \n
  • Web Analytics
    • \n
  • Search Engine Optimization Analysis
    • \n
  • Web Performance Alerts
    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9146964695:\n\n\n\n\n\nOn-Demand Webinar: Web Accessibility and SEO\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

On-Demand Webinar: Web Accessibility Can Boost Your SEO

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

In case having a website that’s accessible to all users wasn’t enough incentive on its own, here’s another reason- it will help boost your SEO rankings. Yeah, true story. On the surface it may not seem like the two are connected, but behind the subtle scenes of your website’s code, proper accessibility practices are providing a major boost to your SEO.

\n

In this on-demand webinar we take a look at not only how web accessibility best practices impact human users and assistive devices, but how it also impacts search engines including: 

\n
    \n
  • Headings and page titles 
    • \n
  • Link Text  
    • \n
  • Image descriptions 
    • \n
  • Semantic mark-up 
    • \n
  • URL's and file names 
    • \n
\n

 

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9028100875:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Prepare for a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

On-Demand Webinar: How to Prepare for a Website Redesign

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Redesigning a website goes much deeper than just the way it looks. Unfortunately, most marketing and web design folks will use this opportunity to focus entirely on the visual design of their website, overlooking the fundamental first step of preparation.

\n

This 30-minute recorded webinar will help you plan, prep, and über organize for a successful website redesign before you start your design process.

\n

What you will learn:
• How to define the purpose of a website redesign
• How to use data for better decision making & redesign planning
• Web Accessibility: What is it and why it’s important to the success of your redesign

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n    \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 9462812025:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove's Webinar: Including People With Disabilities in Your User Testing\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Webinar: Including People With Disabilities in Your User Testing

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Wednesday, November 12, 2014 at 1pm CDT

\n

We’ve talked in the past about having people with disabilities test your webpages. Many of you are interested in doing this, but have asked, “How do I get started?” It doesn’t need to be a complex process, as there are some great resources available if you know where to look, but there are a few different aspects of the process that you will need to consider. 

\n

In this month’s accessibility webinar, we’re going to give you some ideas on implementing a plan for including people with disabilities in your user testing. Topics include:

\n
    \n
  • Getting started
    • \n
  • Recruiting people with disabilities\n
      \n
    • Range of disabilities
      • \n
    \n
    • \n
  • Test environments - planning, live testing, remote testing
    • \n
  • Learning from and working with people with disabilities
    • \n
  • Reporting results
    • \n
\n
\n

About the Host: Kevin Rydberg is Siteimprove’s Senior eAccessibility Consultant, in the US office he is responsible for guiding and supporting businesses and organizations on their journeys to create accessible websites. Kevin has spoken across the globe at multiple conferences and events, most recently in Stockholm for a web accessibility conference. 

\n

Optional Extra: Stick around after the webinar for a quick 15 min overview of our Web Governance Suite software.

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n 8938742605:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Foundations of a Website Redesign\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n

\n
\n
\n

\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\nThe Foundations of a Website Redesign\n

\n

\nPosted by\nStar Bazella\n

\n

\n8/19/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Embarking on a website redesign is no small undertaking. It will require a substantial amount of strategy, organization, and company soul-searching. Not only will you need to ask difficult questions, but you’ll need to provide answers that satisfy every major stakeholder. This prospect alone is enough to deter some organizations from pressing forward, but there are steps you can take in order to not only streamline your redesign project, but ensure that everyone’s needs are met.

\n

\n

Why Redesign Your Website?

\n

Before we get into the specifics, let’s ask my favorite question: “why”? What is the problem with your current website, and what is your goal for the new website?

\n

For some organizations, their current site is simply outdated and needs to be modernized in order to compete in a crowded digital market. For others, the functionality of their site isn’t helping them to achieve their online goals (driving sales, providing information, boosting awareness, etc.)

\n

Before you even begin to think about redesigning your site, you need to answer, “why?”

\n

Content Inventory Audit

\n

Now that you’ve determined why your website needs to be redesigned, and what your goals are, you can begin the process of organizing your assets through a Content Inventory Audit.

\n

This is a simple spreadsheet of all your existing webpages and their corresponding URLs. A Content Inventory Audit is a task often done toward the beginning of a website redesign project, and essential for any [website or intranet] content migration project. It is a great way to think through a redesign but may not be the best way to plan a completely new website.

\n

The spreadsheet stores information about each page on the website; a very handy tool that provides a quick overview of your site.

\n

For most of my projects, I like to collect:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation title, page title and URL for every page
    • \n
  • What's the purpose of the page?
    • \n
  • Who is the target audience of that page?
    • \n
  • More criteria will be covered in the upcoming webinar…
    • \n
\n

As you prepare to add content to the website, think about who will contribute. In a five-person business, it might be just two of you, and that’s fine. In a large business or organization, 5, 10 or 15 people might be contributing content. The time required to edit and proofread both copy and visual content grows exponentially in relation to the number of people who contribute content.

\n

Unless you are creating the most technical website imaginable, your content should consist of more than just plain text. By using one or more of the following multimedia elements, you’ll greatly enhance the appeal and usefulness of the website:

\n
    \n
  • Images & Photo Feeds (Flickr)
    • \n
  • Documents (preferably PDFs)
    • \n
  • Embedded Audio & Video (YouTube & Vimeo)
    • \n
  • Social Media Feeds (Twitter, YouTube, Google+, LinkedIn)
    • \n
  • RSS feeds
    • \n
\n

Content Checklist

\n

Once you’ve mapped out your existing webpages, you can begin to look at the specific content contained within them. The type of content you’re creating will obviously vary depending on your organization’s goals and your audience’s needs, but here is a list of the most common content- this is not even close to an exhaustive list.

\n
    \n
  • Articles
    • \n
  • Blogs
    • \n
  • Banner advertising
    • \n
  • Forms
    • \n
  • Email newsletter
    • \n
  • Event calendar & registration
    • \n
  • Images, Audio, Video
    • \n
  • Social media sharing links [Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.]
    • \n
  • Staff directory etc.
    • \n
\n

Future Content Considerations

\n

Now it’s time to think about future expansion. For example, you might start out with six news items in your news section, each with brief summaries and links to the full view of the item. But what happens when you have 10, 20 or 50 news items? Do you want to archive old news? Paginate the items? Show only the last 10 items? Consider these questions in the design process.

\n

For websites that accumulate content, such as news, press releases and reports, there’s a good rule to follow when creating mock-ups (you can never have enough mock-ups!) In other words, if you think the layout or design of a page or section of the website will differ significantly from other pages, then mocking it up is worthwhile. This step normally comes after the initial mock-ups are approved.

\n

Sitemaps 

\n

A sitemap lists the structure and content of the whole site, roughly similar to the "table of contents" in a book. A sitemap can be an effective planning tool for both designers and non-designers.  It’s a centralized document that can help organize and clarify the content on your site, as well as help you identify future pages and eliminate unnecessary pages.

\n

Sitemaps are made for visitors (people), but they also serve the secondary function of giving search engine crawlers an easy way to find the pages of your site. It is always important to remember when you are making decisions about your site to make those decisions with your visitors first and search engines second.

\n

\n

In the webinar, we’ll cover the different ways to design a sitemap, and the difference between HTML Sitemaps and XML Sitemaps.

\n

Wireframes

\n

Once you’ve determined the structure of the content, you can move to the first step in the design process. Wireframes! A wireframe contains the core components of an individual page, communicating hierarchy, user interface patterns, logic, content types, and potential structure. It’s a representation of how the website interface might work. It is NOT the final visual design or layout.

\n

There are many great tools for this:

\n
    \n
  • Photoshop, Illustrator and Visio works well,
    • \n
  • Specialized tools, like Balsamiq, are my personal favorite
    • \n
\n

\n

It’s important to avoid the desire to make everything look perfect in a wireframe. This phase of the process is meant to help you guide the design, not actually be the design.

\n

You should create a wireframe for each unique page on your site (Homepage, product page, contact page, etc.) It isn’t necessary to create a wireframe for every product page, unless you intend for them to have significantly different layouts and functionalities.

\n

Once the wireframes have gone through your review process with the powers that be, NOW you are allowed to move to the design stage.

\n

Web Style Guide

\n

Last, but not least, in planning out the structure of your website, a Web Style Guide needs to be developed, especially if there are multiple content contributors to your site.

\n

A style guide is where proper planning shines, as it will define all of the design, layout, interactive and type elements used throughout the website.

\n

These include, but are not limited to:

\n
    \n
  • Navigation styles
    • \n
  • <h1> through <h5> (heading tags)
    • \n
  • Paragraphs
    • \n
  • Lists
    • \n
  • Links, including active, hover, and visited states
    • \n
  • Icons
    • \n
  • Use of images and image style
    • \n
  • Use of background images (watermarks)
    • \n
  • Common elements such as sidebars
    • \n
\n

A style guide can also help you start to pay attention to web accessibility standards. If you’re not familiar with web accessibility practices, check out our catalog of web accessibility blogs.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of phasinphoto at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nWebsite Redesign\n

\n
\nStar Bazella\n
\n
\nHi Jennifer! Yes, the webinar will be recorded and available to download from our Resources page by the end of the week.\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\nHarry Jansen\n
\n
\nRevamping a website is no easy task. All the considerations given below, with particular reference to content should be undertaken. Future content considerations, site mapping, space for digital marketing have to be followed. A well written blog on the foundations of a website redesign. Found it to be very useful. Keep posting.\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

Step 1: Write Well. Step 2: Be Successful.

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/16/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The written word has been the cornerstone of human communication since roughly 3,000 B.C. I might be a little biased here, but even as we’ve moved from stone, to pen, to the ever-present keyboard, how you write is more important than ever. The Internet demands good writing. In the Digital Age, your audience’s first interaction with you/your company is often with the words you’ve written. Websites, blogs, social media, email; it’s all vying for the attention of an audience with debilitating A.D.D., and the organizations that prioritize the quality of their web content are the ones who will rise to the top.

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Producing High-Quality Web Content: A Guided Tour

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/9/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

If you're one of those people who can just wake up in the morning, pour yourself a cup of your preferred breakfast-time libation, and start pounding away at your keyboard until something great comes out, we’re officially fighting and I’d like you to leave now.

\n

OK, good. They’re gone.

\n

For us common-folk, creating great content takes time, and it doesn’t happen in a vacuum. It requires a team-effort, as you’ll need input from subject matter experts and buy-in from your co-workers/bosses in order to turn a slab of rock into a piece of chiseled marble.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How to be Agile in a Rigid System with Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n12/2/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

No organization is perfect. Big or small, B2B or B2C, every company faces challenges when it comes to managing their online presence. Resources are scarce, money is tight, and office politics might make you feel like you’re playing the Game of Thrones. You need help to address these issues and find a solution that gets results.

\n
\nRead More\n

Why Blogging Should Be Part Of Your Web Governance Strategy

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/24/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The “too long; didn’t read” version? It’s good for business. Oh, you’re still there. Well then let’s elaborate on that a little bit. When done correctly, blogging is arguably the most important, and most effective, inbound marketing tactic your organization can utilize. According to HubSpot, blogging regularly will result in more sales leads, more site visits, and more social media engagement. See? We told you it’s good for business.

\n

Now, for you detail-oriented readers, let’s take a closer look at how blogging can have a positive impact on your other marketing and web governance strategies and help you reach your online marketing goals.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Content Marketing and Website Governance are, like, Totally BFFs

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n6/10/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

“Keep telling me what to do and what to buy”, said no consumer ever. Mass marketing tactics such as TV, print, and radio were once the staples of every marketing strategy. But, thanks to the Internet, they have seen their share of the budget eaten away by a new brand of more carefully curated strategies that are able to leverage websites, social media, and email. One such strategy is Content Marketing, which aims to attract a highly targeted audience by developing and sharing content that has been designed specifically with them in mind.   

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What We Learned At Confab Central 2014

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/22/14 9:30 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

What is Confab? It’s a 3-day conference aimed at sharing knowledge among professionals who understand the value of creating awesome content. People with backgrounds in Marketing, Design, User Experience, I.T., and Business all come together and challenge one another to think about things in new ways, approach problems with new tactics, and share their successes and #EpicFails in equal measure.

\n

We went as knowledge sponges. Here’s some of the stuff we soaked up.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

How Will the Net Neutrality Rulings Impact Consumers and Businesses?

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n5/9/14 9:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

The debate over Net Neutrality has intensified once again and will likely continue to do so as Internet Service Providers like Comcast and Verizon push for a Federal Communications Commission (FCC) ruling in their favor on May 20, 2014. The outcome of this debate could have drastic impacts on the way consumers and businesses use the Internet as a communication and information sharing platform, so make sure you know what it could mean for you and your company.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

New website – Think web accessibility from day 1

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/29/12 4:40 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If you are about to redesign your website, now is a good time to focus on getting a website that can be used by as many people as possible. Here are some tips on when and how to make requirements and focus on accessibility throughout the process.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle

\n

\nPosted by\nBarbara Hammer-Aebi\n

\n

\n8/22/12 4:41 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Create an annual search cycle to stay one step ahead of your users

\n
\n

If your website has an internal search bar, it's a good idea to always be working on your internal search statistics. If you want to stay a step ahead of your users, you can create an annual cycle detailing search queries by month.  Then you can track and measure which areas need to be prioritized and given more effort.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nEnterprise Search\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Avoid These Common Accessibility Mistakes

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n8/8/12 4:47 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Find out if you use alternative texts, headings and forms correctly and if you in general help people with disabilities and dyslexia etc. on your website

\n

In this blog, we'll cover several common misunderstandings in connection with accessibility problems on websites. Find out whether your website is doing it right or wrong.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nWeb Governance Ask Us Anything Preview #2\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n7/29/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

As our panel of experts are busy answering the brain-busting questions submitted for our Ask Us Anything, we thought we'd share a sneak peek at the wisdom of our friend and Web Governance expert, Shane Diffily.

\n

You can download the full Ask Us Anything recording here.

\n

OK, I know. "Stop talking and give us the goods." 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

 

\n

\n
\n

Question:

\n

We have a small team which makes it difficult to be proactive about improving our website. All we do is put out fires. What can we do get out in front of problems without spending a ton of money or hiring more staff?

\n

Answer:

\n

 Shane Diffily - Author & Web Governance Consultant 

\n

"Constant firefighting and an inability to focus on important things are classic Web Governance problems.

\n

There are two usual causes...

\n

The first is that the level of resourcing available to you (people, tools, money, etc.) and the amount of activity you have to expedite (content, visitor engagement, tech issues, etc.) are out of balance.

\n

(Find out more about imbalance in Web Governance at www.diffily.com/governance)

\n

The second is that there is some issue in how your online governance is configured that prevents you from doing everything expected of you.

\n

Although most cases display a mixture of both, my own experience suggests that the first cause is most prevalent.

\n

Legitimate expectations

\n

\n

The majority of web teams are WAY under-resourced. They are unfairly asked to cope with ever increasing volumes & complexity on shoe-string budgets.

\n

Although it may not be feasible for you to get extra funding for your team, you can at least flag this imbalance and point out the risks it creates.

\n

As an Online Manager, you have a legitimate expectation that adequate resources will be provided to you to get the job done.

\n

If that is not the case, in many ways, it is not your problem.

\n

It is Senior Management's duty to ensure you have enough of everything to do your job. If they choose to ignore that responsibility, they also choose to accept the risks it involves.

\n

For example, too many demands for content and too few editorial staff will inevitably result in errors in content. The problem is not shoddy work by staff. The problem is an out-of-balance governance system.

\n

When the burden of activity exceeds your ability to cope, your organization’s online reputation is at risk “by design”.

\n

But on the other hand…

\n

Almost every web operation contains inefficiencies that detract from your ability to get things done. Simply fixing such issues can free up surprising amounts of resources, which can then be applied elsewhere.

\n

(Find out how to detect issues in Web Governance at http://www.diffily.com/articles/governanceanalytics.htm)

\n

One of the most common inefficiencies is how requests for new work are accepted by a web team.

\n

You may have seen it printed on a cheeky coffee mug in your office. “A lack of planning on your part, does not constitute an emergency on my part.”

\n

The chaos of the early internet resulted in many informal procedures for getting stuff online. The problem is that these have often persisted way past their use-by date.

\n

If you find that your operations are constantly disrupted by “urgent” requests for content or design changes, it is a sure sign that you need to reformulate your processes.

\n

Internal customers must accept that you cannot continue to spin on a dime every time they want to put out a press release. They need to plan ahead and notify you well in advance (at a minimum of a week) of any work they need done. It is then up to you to dictate the timeframe for completing their project. 

\n

Making it happen

\n

Of course, I understand that making such a change may not be easy. But you can be sure that everyone else would insist on running their own departments that way, and so will not be able to argue against your own desire to improve efficiency.

\n

To help make things happen, your Senior Manager must also back you up. He/she should circulate an email to say there is a new process and everyone must get onboard.

\n

Building-in an exception process is also a good idea.

\n

We must accept that occasionally there will be things that are genuinely unexpected that must get to the front of the queue.

\n

Appease any worried customers by explaining that they will continue to have access to such a procedure in-extremis, whilst also making it clear that misuse has consequences too."

\n
\n

 

\n

Download the full Ask Us Anything recording by clicking on the link below

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792103605:\n\n\n\n\n\nHow to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
