\n

\nHow to Increase Conversions with Proper Web Design\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n11/25/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Conversions are measurable actions that users complete on your website, things like: completed purchases, form submissions, button clicks, video views, document downloads, or specific page views. Every website exists (hopefully) with a specific goal or purpose, and while the types of conversions may vary between different organizations, they all share the same desire to provide their audience with a solution to their needs.

\n\n

The way your website presents itself, and the way in which users interact with it, will have a significant impact on your organization’s ability to increase conversions and achieve its goals.

\n

Let’s take a look at some of the web design elements that can influence users and increase conversions.

\n

Navigation & Layout (User Experience)

\n

Think of the user experience of your website as how it “feels”, “functions”, and “flows”. Your site’s navigation needs to provide users with access to the content they need, in the fewest amount of steps possible.

\n

Poor website navigation has the same result as a driver encountering a “roundabout” for the first time. Common reactions include: “How did I get here?” “where am I going?" and, “how do I get out of here?"

\n

It goes without saying that your navigation should follow a logical progression, so the difficult question to answer is, which content will receive the most prominent placement within your site’s navigation?

\n

The answer can be found in a number of ways, but fastest and easiest way is to look at your analytics. Your analytics will reveal which pages your users visit most often, which ones receive the most interactions, and which ones aren’t quite cutting it. You won’t be able to please everyone all the time, so don’t even try. Instead, use this information to design your site’s navigation in a way that best serves your audience and your business needs.

\n

Aesthetics (User Interface)

\n

The user interface pertains to the interactive elements of a website- the text users will read, the buttons they will click, and the media they will view.

\n

Have you ever visited a website that was a little too “busy”? Instantly, you’re barraged by content, video, images, dozens of links, and endless choices. These types of sites often fail to present users with a clear path forward, like being dropped into the middle of a jungle with nothing but a canteen, a machete, and pat on the back for good luck.

\n

Humans are visual creatures. According to the Social Science Research Network, 65% of the population are visual learners. We like things that we think are pretty: pretty cars, pretty houses, pretty clothes, and pretty websites.

\n

A site can have great navigation, but if it looks “messy”, your users will never know it. They be too put off by the dated design, confusing color palette, or jumbled font treatments. Whether you base it on your business goals, or the information gleaned from your analytics data, the visual treatments of your website should drive users toward the most important content.

\n

Responsive Design

\n

Desktops, laptops, iPhones, iPads, Android phones, Android Tablets, Windows Phones, Windows Surface, overwhelmed yet? Think about how your website feels when it’s constantly forced to be zoomed, scrolled, pinched, and swiped across so many devices.

\n

Originally defined by Ethan Marcotte, Responsive Design is a byproduct of the web’s versatility and variety. With so many different devices, platforms, and mediums on which to view content, the digital world needed to free itself from the rigid constraints that carried over from print publications.

\n

Rather than forcing every device to find a way to house and navigate your website, usually through clunky scrolling and zooming, Responsive design allows your website to automatically adjust its size, layout, appearance, and functionality based on the user’s chosen device.

\n

Mobile Friendly

\n

Mobile use is growing faster than any other platform in the world, and will continue to do so as the technology behind it continues to evolve. If you don’t think your organization needs to prioritize its mobile strategy, think about this:

\n
    \n
  • Smartphone usage is expected to reach 2 billion by the end of 2015
    • \n
  • American’s spent 34 hours per month viewing the web/apps on their mobile devices in 2013- 7 hours more than they did on their computers
    • \n
  • Mobile devices account for 80% of China’s Internet traffic
    • \n
\n

Responsive design will help make your site mobile friendly by adjusting the layout to fit within the smaller sandbox, but that isn’t the whole story. The mobile environment requires a few extra considerations in order to provide users with the optimal experience:

\n

Touchscreen interfaces

\n

Save for a few stubborn holdouts, smartphones and tablets have fully embraced the touchscreen, which changes how users are able to interact with the “clickable” elements of your website. The usability of a website changes dramatically when the primary method of input changes from a mouse click to a finger tap.

\n

Take this into consideration when deciding where to place these elements, and how they are presented.

\n

File sizes and download speeds

\n

Remember that mobile users can be anywhere at any time, at that their Internet connection can range from “passable” to “oh my god, let’s go!” You can help them access your site faster by keeping its loading time down.

\n

Don’t bog down your mobile site with unnecessary elements, heavy visual treatments, or large images/videos.

\n

Vertical hierarchy

\n

Using a “single column” layout on your mobile site helps you cope with the limited space allotted by mobile devices. It also helps your content scale between different devices and viewing modes (portrait vs. landscape).

\n

This vertical, single column environment can sometimes lead to what’s known as the “endless scroll”. This happens when content that would normally stretch horizontally across a site is condensed into a slender space.

\n

You can combat this by adjusting the amount and length of content presented on your mobile site, or by implementing a collapsible navigation. A collapsible navigation will allow you to stack large amounts of content underneath drop-down menus that can be easily opened or closed.

\n

For more help on creating a usable, functional website, download our Foundations of a Website Redesign Webinar.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Design\n

3 Necessary Activities & Skills for Effective Web Analytics

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n10/21/14 10:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Getting an effective digital analytics process in place is a common challenge faced by many organizations. It’s often a problem of not understanding what an effective process looks like, or knowing what’s needed to carry that process out.

\n

This leads to the wrong resources being used, essential steps being passed over, and/or underestimating the amount of resources needed to get this right. In the upcoming webinar, we’ll take a look at the three main activities an organization must perform for effective digital analysis and the three skills needed to perform those activities well. By attending this webinar, attendees will have a better understanding of how to implement a process that works and the resources needed to do so.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Adding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n

Make Campaign Tracking Part of Your Website Measuring Process

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/22/14 12:07 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In order to fully understand the success of your digital marketing efforts you need the complete picture. In this post we will review a key component to capturing information you may be missing, how to implement that process in your organization and provide some guidance on how to add some serious value when you are armed with a more complete data set.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n

How to Track Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions With Events

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:57 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Website technology has evolved so fast that tracking meaningful interactions can be difficult: White paper downloads, form submissions, and even watching informational videos can all be seen as KPIs and/or MCs, but are often impossible to track with the “out of the box” functionality of most web analytics tools. If you want to track these critical data points, you need to customize your tracking code – a seemingly daunting task.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Identifying Key Performance Indicators and Micro Conversions on B2B Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:22 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

This past week I had the opportunity to talk to both the Tampa and Orlando City Groups of the Legal Marketing Association (LMA) Southeastern Chapter about getting value from their web analytics. As with any good analytics framework, there are some key things you can do to begin making meaningful changes to your websites based on data.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A Different Approach to SEO for Law Firms

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n8/13/13 10:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Rand Fishkin of Moz addressed the argument brewing in the broader world of Search Engine Optimization strategy: Link Building vs. Content Marketing. While this discussion has flown beneath the radar for most legal marketers, it is clear which side is best for today’s corporate law firm: Content Marketing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n

\n

\nOn page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n\n
\n

With panda Google aims to weed out content without substance, ie sites with thin, useless, or just low quality content, in order to improve search results. Focus used to be on relevance, but now quality is just as important. It is no longer enough to find the right keywords and make sure to put them in the right places on the page. Now you also have to consider the user experience of the website as a whole, and whether it is a website that users like, trust, want to spend time on and  share with others in social media. Therefore, it is a good idea to follow these 3 tips if you want to future proof your website:

 1. Create good quality content - site wide

\n

First of all your content must be unique, grammatically correct, free of spelling errors and dead links. It also needs to be useful, informative, interesting and/or fresh. A website that is never updated does not give the impression of being particularly interesting. Last but not least, the quality must apply to the entire site as a whole. So you might want to remove low quality pages - or update them to become useful and interesting.


 2. Ensure great design and user experience

\n

Back in the day, you could search engine optimize a website, regardless of how it looked. That is not the case anymore. Both design and usability must be of great quality, ie. great graphics and images. Ads should not take up too much space. The usability of menu, structure, buttons, etc. must be considered. As an extra benefit, you can expect to harvest more links, more user activity, social media shares, likes and tweets, if you do it properly.

\n


3. Use statistics to investigate user behavior in order to improve it

\n

You can use statistics to identify sites of poor quality. Look at how much time the user has spent on site, bounce rate, page views, direct traffic, etc. Which pages have none or very little traffic? Which has a high bounce rate? Which receive poor user feedback? Pages that stick out and are of poor quality should be addressed. Additionally, you can also use the statistics tool to keep an eye on whether the changes you make to the website in general also improve user experience.

Quality takes time, and there are no quick short cuts if you want to future proof your website. Use your statistics tool wisely, and once you have removed poor quality content, then start improving your most important pages first. Then you can work your way down to lower level pages as time allows

Find more information about what Google sees as quality content on Google's own blog.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792130185:\n\n\n\n\n\nAccessible Website Multimedia\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nAccessible Website Multimedia\n

\n

\nPosted by\nKevin Rydberg\n

\n

\n9/18/14 12:27 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

According to HubSpot, multimedia content is more engaging and shareable than its text-only counterparts. Making this content more accessible for your users is a simple process, so long as you take web accessibility guidelines into account while adding this kind of content to your website. With improvements in bandwidth, as well as browsers and media players, you have an opportunity to deliver an engaging, rich media experience to your visitors. Unfortunately, if you don’t prepare properly, the experience will be less accessible, and more frustrating to your visitors.

\n\n

WCAG time-based media criteria

\n

Guideline 1.2 Time-based Media:

\n

This guideline says to provide alternatives for time-based media; the purpose is to offer equal access to multimedia content. What is time-based media? Time-based media is simply a term that represents different formats of content that purposely changes or flows over time. Examples may include:

\n
    \n
  • Movies
    • \n
  • Audio clips
    • \n
  • Or animations
    • \n
\n

Let’s try to keep this simple. If you are using prerecorded or live media, (video or audio), you need to be sure there are transcripts, captions, or audio descriptions available.

\n
    \n
  • Offer a transcript or audio description for pre-recorded video content or pre-recorded audio (1.2.1, A)
    • \n
  • Provide captions for pre-recorded multimedia (1.2.2, A)
    • \n
  • Offer captions for live multimedia (1.2.4, AA)
    • \n
\n

“Wait a minute,” you say, “you mentioned animations…”

\n

I’m glad to see that you’re paying attention! Just be sure that your animated content has an acceptable text description.

\n

Pro tip 1: Captions and transcripts are good for searchability and SEO. Just sayin’.

\n

Keyboard traps

\n

What is a keyboard trap? A trap is when you are able to use the keyboard to navigate to a component or feature of a page, but then unable to navigate away from that feature.

\n

Media player accessibility

\n

A common example of a keyboard trap is typically a media player. Just be sure your users are able to navigate through or past the player with the keyboard.

\n

Pro tip 2: Be sure to design focus states so the keyboard user can see the active component on the screen.

\n

Video delivery systems

\n

YouTube

\n

Using YouTube for video delivery is a good idea for a variety of reasons. Not only is it a free service, but it also has global reach, and is incredibly reliable. YouTube has done a pretty good job of providing accessible accommodations, too. That said, there are a few problems to consider. Keyboard traps can be a problem with embedded players, so be careful when developing your video delivery system. Be sure to use the HTML5 version of the YouTube player instead of the Flash player; It’s much more accessible.

\n

With a quick Google search for YouTube and accessibility, you will see a variety of resources for screen reader users, captioning services, and accessible player APIs/scripts. With such a large community offering accessible solutions, you should be able to offer accessible YouTube videos on your website. If you are unsure if your videos are accessible, you will want to rely on a screen reader user to fully test your video player.

\n

Vimeo

\n

In January 2014, Vimeo updated its web-based video player with an HTML5 version, which greatly improved video delivery and accessibility. While there may still be room for improvement, the Vimeo player has good keyboard and screen reader support, and also supports captions and subtitles. You can consider Vimeo as a solid video delivery solution, especially as they continue to consider accessibility in future updates.

\n

HTML5

\n

Before HTML5, online videos could only be played using a plug-in like Flash. The <video> element of HTML5 offered a better, standard way to add video to a website. Cross-browser support and an almost unlimited library of scripts have allowed HTML5 to become the de facto method for online video. Mobile devices also offer excellent support for HTML5 <video>.

\n

 

\n

In this month’s web accessibility webinar, we’re going to discuss how to ensure that your multimedia content is accessible to people with disabilities by discussing how to meet WCAG guidelines, and then provide you with a few ways to begin improving your website’s multimedia delivery.

\n

\n \n \n

\n

Image courtesy of Stuart Miles at FreeDigitalPhotos.net

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792134585:\n\n\n\n\n\nWeb Editors: Create Accessible Websites\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWeb Editors: Create Accessible Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n1/29/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web editor you are responsible for the content you publish on the website and it’s accessibility. Do you know how to support accessibility when you write texts and add images and links on a web page?

\n
\n
\n

This is the final blog post in a series of 3 that cover websites and accessibility with a role-based approach. This post is meant for web editors. The previous was intended for web designers and for web developers. I will give concrete tips on how to create an accessible web site.

\n

Include the remaining 20% of users

\n

Surveys show that up to 20% of web users are affected by accessibility issues when surfing the web. By following the principles of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines you ensure that as many people as possible can use a website. In the following paragraphs I will give tips on which criteria are relevant for you as a web editor.

\n

Page titles

\n

In a CMS, you give a web page a title or name when you create it. In some systems there is also a specific field for this called "Title." It's important that this title is descriptive of what the page is about, because it's shown in the top of your browser and is the first thing on a web page to be read by a screen reader.

\n

Text

\n

When writing text for web pages, consider the fact that some users can't get an overview of a page visually, as opposed to structurally. Make sure that pages are divided into logical sections, each given a heading that is descriptive of the section. You can use several levels of headings: heading 1, heading 2, etc. (in the code <h1>, <h2> etc., so that assistive technologies can render them as headings).

\n

Because of low vision, some users will perceive a web page very differently from the way other users would visually perceive it. Make sure to not give important information solely by the use of color or with an instruction requiring sensory skills. As an example, avoid writing things like: "… you can read more about the event in the blue box to the right."

\n

It's fine to write something like this if you supplement it with something that all users can find, such as an additional text: "… you can read more about the event in the blue box to the right by the heading 'Events in March." This way you're also giving details that all users will be able to find.

\n

If you change the language in the text, make sure you state the language of that piece of text. In the code this is done with the attribute lang="" for the text unit. A good CMS will allow you to highlight the piece of text and choose language from a drop down menu.

\n

Links

\n

When you add links on a page, write link texts that make sense when read out of context. For instance, avoid using link texts such as "Read more," "here," "Click here," "publication," etc. An example could be: "You can read more about the Assistive Technologies event here." Another example could be writing: "You can read more about the Assistive Technologies event here." It would be better to write "You can read more about the Assistive Technologies event here" for example. This way you are giving a link text that in itself is a good indicator of what the destination page is about.

\n

Images

\n

When you add images to a web page, consider the fact that some users cannot see images and need a text alternative. In most CMSs this is stated as "alternative text" or "alt text." The text given here is not visually displayed on the page, but is hidden in the code to be accessed by screen readers. (The alternative text is not the same as a tooltip: The text displayed when you hover over the image called "title").

\n

Try to close your eyes and visualise what information you need if you cannot see the image. Describe the purpose of the image and not necessarily what the image is of. If the image is linking it is important to describe where the link goes to/what happens when clicking on the image. If the image is solely used for decorative purposes, creating an ambience or a visual context, it should have no alternative text. If the image contains information, that information should be given in the alternative text.

\n

Avoid using images of text. This means that you should avoid, for instance, writing a text in an image editing program and save it as an image. Many of the types of software that reads text aloud (for instance those used by dyslexics) cannot read images of text. This is because you can't highlight text within an image to have it read out loud to you. (Some of these types of software can read alternative texts but far from all. They should not be confused with screen reader software used by the visually impaired. These are much more advanced).

\n

Video and audio

\n

If you are using video or audio clips on a web page there are several criteria to consider, such as captioning and audio description on video. Audio description is an extra track that lets a visually impaired user know what's happening on the screen. If you are not able to provide your videos with audio description, give an alternative in the form of a transcript that is uploaded or linked to from the page. But be aware that without audio description you cannot be AA compliant but only A-compliant.

\n

If the content is solely visual (no sound) or only audio (no visual) then a text version is an accepted alternative on both levels.

\n

Tables

\n

When using data tables with information, it's important to indicate headings for rows and/or columns. The way to do this is very CMS specific. In some cases the editor provides an accessibility tab where this information can be entered when using data tables.

\n

Lists

\n

When using a list of items make sure to use the function for this that is built into the editor in the CMS. This will ensure that the right and accessible code is entered for lists. Avoid just making dots that looks like a list (such as asterisk, dash etc.).

\n

 

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n
\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792135145:\n\n\n\n\n\nCorporate Responsibility at Siteimprove\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nCorporate Responsibility at Siteimprove\n

\n

\nPosted by\nCamilla Simonsen\n

\n

\n4/25/12 11:21 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

At Siteimprove we work with Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) as an essential part of the growth we experience in our three main markets in the UK, USA and in Denmark. A lot of initiatives have already been introduced, for instance we work hard to contribute to a higher degree of Web Accessibility on public and private websites. We wish to minimize our carbon footprint and offer our employees a sound and exciting working environment, in order to encourage employees to create new and even better Web Governance solutions for our customers.

\n
\n\n

It's somewhat atypical for a software company like Siteimprove to be working with Corporate Social Responsibility. Our production isn't environmentally damaging and we don't have production or activities in Third World countries, however we do believe that all businesses, regardless of size, should contribute to the global environmental and social challenges. That being said it's also very important that our customers and partners know that we "behave properly."

\n

The last two years have been momentous to the company. The turnover has increased by 75%, the Siteimprove family has grown by 35 new employees and we're moving into three new markets in Canada, Sweden and Germany. This means that things are moving really fast in our three offices in Copenhagen, London and Minneapolis, which is exactly why it's important to ensure not only economical growth but also responsible growth.

\n

To demonstrate how serious we are on this matter, we joined the UN initiative Global Compact in 2010, and thereby commit ourselves to publish a yearly report (Communication on Progress) that gives an insight to the responsible initiatives we have worked with through the past year.

\n

The 3 main areas we work with within CSR: Human Rights, Labor, and Environment. A few of the main areas we have chosen to focus on are:

\n

Human Rights

\n

Contributing to a higher degree of Web Accessibility and thereby show regard to all types of Internet users in digitization.

\n
    \n
  • Free consultancy on Web Accessibility through blog posts, seminars and webinars.
    • \n
  • Pro Bono collaboration with an NGO to increase and disseminate knowledge about Web Accessibility. (Later we will give more details about the collaboration, which is still in its initial phase.)
    • \n
  • Optimization of the 'Siteimprove Accessibility' service, which makes it easier for webmaster on all levels to offer users accessible websites that meet international standards for accessibility (WCAG 2.0).
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Climate & Environment: To reduce our energy consumption and carbon footprint
    • \n
\n
    \n
  • Siteimprove have signed a climate partnership agreement with DONG Energy, (the leading energy company in Denmark) which means that we have identified our energy consumption and saving potential and continuously work in a number of areas in order to ensure that Siteimprove becomes a more sustainable company.
    • \n
\n

Labor

\n
To ensure happy employees who offer customers excellent products and great service
\n
    \n
  • The sharp minds of the Siteimprove employees is our core business, as all our 'production' takes place in the brains of our employees. 
    • \n
  • A prerequisite for being able to offer customers excellent products and great service is that we can attract and retain qualified employees by offering a sound working environment.
    • \n
\n

 

\n

Do you want to know more or let us know what you think?

\n

CSR is still a new world to us. In 2011 we published the first Siteimprove Responsibility Report, which gives you an insight into what we do. We welcome any feedback and ideas on how to strengthen our corporate social responsibility in the future - the second Responsibility Report is just around the corner.

\n

Please feel free to email interesting ideas directly to the CSR manager Camilla Simonsen at cas@siteimprove.dk

\n

 

\n
\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792135555:\n\n\n\n\n\nWhy do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nWhy do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?\n

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n4/18/12 11:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Web professionals looking to improve their website accessibility using Siteimprove tools are finding that they have more issues in Quality Assurance, than they had in the former SiteCheck, but they are unsure of why.

\n
\n\n

"Why do I suddenly have more accessibility issues?" is a question I am frequently getting from our customers.

\n

We are in a process of migrating our customers to our new Web Governance Suite. For this reason we are getting a lot of requests on why, when using our tools, one all of a sudden has other issues and more issues than previously. A frequent question is also why issues that customers used to focus on in the previous interface are no longer present in the new interface and why everything looks so different.

\n

One of the reasons for this is that the accessibility guidelines are different and therefore results from testing for accessibility have also changed. Actually the current version of the accessibility guidelines, WCAG 2.0, was given the status of being the recommended version in December 2008.

\n

Some radical changes have been made since version 1.0. One of the major changes is that WCAG 2.0 allows the use of not only W3C technologies but also other types of web technologies. At the same time a number of level AA or level AAA issues have moved to level A. Some criteria are no longer relevant and have been removed. Others have been introduced (A comparison of WCAG 1.0 and WCAG 2.0 is given here ).

\n

The way we test for accessibility has also changed with this shift. Therefore it is not possible to simply 'convert' a test tool and a test set so that it does the same just in a 'version 2' instead of a 'version 1'.

\n

This has been an extensive process of change for the WCAG working group in WAI whom have developed version 2.0. It has also been a major process of change for us who created the tool that tests for WCAG conformance. Finally it will be a process of change for those using the tool to test and ensure conformance of the accessibility guidelines.

\n

The good news about all this is that we are all helping to ensure improved accessibility on websites and we are doing it in a more up-to-date manner in terms of the technologies that are now used on the Internet.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n

\n
\n

\nsusie grace\n
\n
\nLooking forward to learning more about web accessibility\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792140485:\n\n\n\n\n\nSearch Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSearch Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites\n

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n\n
\n

First and foremost it's important to note that SEO for mobile websites is almost the same as for standard websites. The main difference is that local results are weighed higher on mobile searches. But even if you have complete control over the SEO of your website, you may still encounter problems depending on the mobile website model you choose.

1) The easiest solution (but not necessarily the best) is to do nothing at all. If you already have a user friendly and search engine optimized website, it's possible to leave it at that. Smartphones do a really good job of displaying standard websites, but often the user will have to use the phone's zoom function to be able to read the text and hit the right links and buttons. This method isn't the most user friendly, but your website will be visible to mobile users. Try to visit your website via a smartphone and test the navigation. If you get annoyed by the lack of speed and usability, you should strongly consider one of the other options.

2) Another option is "responsive design," which is about designing a website that provides a good user experience regardless of which device you use to access the site. That means the design is scalable so that the same page looks different depending on whether you visit the site via a smartphone, tablet, or desktop PC. On a smartphone, you would typically see one long column with the different components which on a desktop PC will typically be displayed in several columns:

\n


\n

From an SEO perspective, this is the best method to create a mobile friendly website. The main advantage of this model is that you only have one version of the website and one URL. This makes it easy to manage - there aren't two different versions of the site to be maintained and optimized - and you avoid taking a position on the SEO problems that can be a result of separate URLs. It also gives a good user experience because users always see the same site, although the elements may be arranged slightly different. On the downside, it often requires a redesign/adaptation of the design and code of the website. Both Google and Bing recommend this solution.

3) The third option is to create a separate website for the mobile market on a separate URL. This way you avoid making changes to the design of your existing website. One of the drawbacks of this model is that you get two versions of the website that have to be administered and maintained. However, there may well be good reasons for choosing this model, for example, if mobile users are using the site for significantly different purposes than desktop users. This example shows how the HSBC/Bank of America mobile website considers how their mobile users are typically interested in online banking and local content and making that content easily available (note how they also link to the desktop version at the bottom): 

\n

 

\n

There are different opinions in the SEO community as to whether a separate mobile URL poses a risk of problems such as duplicate content and link juice dilution. So if you choose this option, be cautious and follow Google's guidelines carefully.

\n

When choosing which way to go, it is important that you use your analytical data to assess your mobile users' behavior and develop a mobile strategy that takes into account what content your mobile users are looking for. As explained in last week's blog post about websites for mobile devices, this may also save you a lot of money.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n

The Challenge of Maintaining Consistent Website Content

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n4/30/14 11:13 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Updating your website with new content is essential for increasing search traffic, but it can also create content management headaches as your site grows and your content strategy evolves.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Why Content Governance Drives Engagement

\n

\nPosted by\nAhava Leibtag\n

\n

\n4/10/14 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

In honor of President’s Day, my husband and I took our three children to the American Museum of History, a branch of the Smithsonian in Washington, D.C. While we were putting our coats in lockers, I saw something that surprised me:

\n
\n

Does stash seem like a word that is in line with Smithsonian brand? Stash feels a little too irreverent to be a Smithsonian word. Yet, when I saw this sign, it became clear to me:

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nContent Governance,\nContent\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792150925:\n\n\n\n\n\nSiteimprove Announces US Relocation\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n

\nSiteimprove Announces US Relocation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/14/14 3:41 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove, the leading provider of Web Governance tools, has relocated their Minneapolis office due to rapid growth in 2013.

\n
\n
\n

On January 2, 2014, Siteimprove US moved into a new office located at 8000 Norman Center Drive, Suite 300, Minneapolis, MN 55437 as part of a major workforce expansion.

\n

Siteimprove’s Minneapolis branch grew significantly in 2013, adding more than 250 new customers and 13 employees.

\n

“The new office opens new doors for Siteimprove,” said Torben Rytt, CEO. “Our recent expansion paves the way for new hires, which means the ability to pursue new and existing markets, improve customer service, and strengthen organizational infrastructure. Siteimprove staff and services are growing quickly, and our new location will help to sustain that growth.” 

\n

The new 11,000 square foot office doubles the 5,500 square foot space Siteimprove previously held in Uptown, Minneapolis, and adds flexibility for further expansion with additional available space nearby.

\n

The additional space was put to use immediately, as Siteimprove welcomed several new employees within the first week after finishing the move to the new office. New positions are consistently available on the Siteimprove Careers page.

\n

“The new space eases congestion and has simplified the process of on boarding several key additions to our team. Because of this, Siteimprove customers can continue to expect the same top-notch customer service and attention to detail they’ve always enjoyed despite the rapid growth of our customer base.” said Rytt.

\n

Since 2003, Siteimprove has provided industry leading Web Governance tools to thousands of organizations worldwide. Headquartered in Copenhagen, Denmark with offices in Minneapolis and London, Siteimprove has a strong presence in dozens of countries across North America, Europe, and the Middle East. Siteimprove’s Web Governance Suite, offered via Software as a Service [SaaS], helps organizations manage and maintain their large websites through web quality assurance, web accessibility, web analytics, SEO analysis and web performance alerts.

\n
\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792153585:\n\n\n\n\n\nThe Web Governance Food Pyramid\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\n
\n
\n

\nThe Web Governance Food Pyramid\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/26/14 10:02 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

Don’t worry, I’m not here to tell you that 4 cups of coffee a day and a granola bar for lunch doesn’t constitute proper adult nutrition. In fact, top that off with a pack of Twizzlers® and a Red Bull® and you’ve got yourself the first meal out of the official Corporate America Cookbook (on newsstands never). However, I am going to tell you that your Web Governance Strategy needs to have a solid structure and balanced combination of essential components in order to properly manage and maintain your organization’s online presence.

\n

And what might those components be? I’m glad you asked.

\n

\n

\n

Resources

\n

Resources comprise all of the tools, software, and hardware that your web team uses to create, publish, and monitor your web content. This includes things like your CMS (WordPress), publishing tools (HubSpot), and web governance tools (*cough*Siteimprove*cough*).

\n

If your web governance strategy were a house, think of your resources as the physical tools you would use to build and maintain it, like hammers, screwdrivers, and paintbrushes.

\n

People

\n

Your web team; the ones who do the heavy lifting when it comes to creating content, fixing potential errors, and ensuring a consistent user experience.

\n

The Roles & Responsibilities for your web team should be clearly defined in order to prioritize projects, avoid miscommunication over who is responsible for addressing certain tasks, and spread the workload evenly among the team.

\n

If your web governance strategy were a house, think of your people as the ones building the frame, installing the wires, and putting on the fresh coat of paint.

\n

Process

\n

How you do what you do. Your process defines how and why content is created, where it gets published, and who is responsible for monitoring its performance. This should include your social media, SEO, and analytics practices, as all of these pieces will help you identify the content that resonates with your audience.

\n

Knowing what works and what doesn’t will allow you to tailor future content around your audience’s needs, and update older content to be more relevant.

\n

If your web governance strategy were a house, think of your process as the workflow that dictates which pieces of the house get built first (foundation, frame, wiring, walls, fixtures, etc)

\n

Policy & Standards

\n

We recently detailed the difference between Policies and Standards, but they’re essentially the guidelines which detail your organization’s online goals and how you plan to achieve them.

\n

These should be broad, high-level ideas that are shared by the entire organization, but with a twist that applies to the digital ecosystem.

\n

If your Web Governance strategy were a house, think of your Policy & Standards as the blueprint. It should act as a point of reference for your team to work from in order to reach your goals.

\n

Now that your website is on the path to healthy living, download our helpful web governance checklist to make sure you keep it that way.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792154095:\n\n\n\n\n\nGet Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n

\nGet Ready for CONFAB Minneapolis 2013\n

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n6/3/13 2:45 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Many people (ourselves included) are excitedly gearing up for the 2013 CONFAB Minneapolis Conference kicking off today. A great event that spans three days, this year’s conference is completely sold out - but it doesn’t mean those of you who don’t have tickets need to miss out.

\n
\n
\n

We’ll be in attendance both as participants and exhibitors, and over the next week we look forward to rounding up all the information we’ve learned and sharing it with you.

\n

To get people excited though we have decided to start by looking at just what exactly CONFAB is, and why it’s such a popular event.

The brainchild of the aptly named “Brain Traffic,” a Minneapolis based content strategy consultancy firm, CONFAB is the world’s leading content strategy conference. Bringing together professionals from around the world, the event is marketed towards those who realize the value of content – regardless of what industry they operate in.

The movers and shakers behind the conference label it, “one big party for content-loving folks who value smart thinking, voracious learning, and constant improvement in the workplace and beyond.” Following on from an extremely successful debut, the conference is now in its third year.

While the concept of content strategy may not be new, the CONFAB conference did revolutionize the way in which people around the world talk, write and think about content strategy. Indeed one only has to do an internet search for ‘content strategy’ to be bombarded with a wealth of information about what it is, and how to do it. Explaining the effect CONFAB has had on people, the organizers claim “Attendees posted recaps, held ‘redux’ sessions, started meet-ups, and shared success stories. There were career changes, new budgets, and increased influence in the workplace—all as a result of what they learned at Confab.”     

With more than 30 speakers crammed into three days people are sure to be spoiled for choice, but one lovely lady people won’t want to miss is Kristina Halvorson – the opening keynote speaker and the CEO and founder of Brain Traffic.

In our opinion Kristina is without a doubt one of, if not, the world’s leading authorities on content strategy. Having founded Brain Traffic in 2002 she has merely gone from strength to strength, and her influential article ‘The Discipline of Content Strategy’ was fundamental in bringing content strategy to the forefront.

\n

Apart from initiating her first conference in 2009 – the Content Strategy Consortium, she also published her book ‘Content Strategy for the Web’, which, at the time was the only book published on the topic, and is today considered the gold standard for content strategy literature.

So for all your CONFAB related news be sure to follow us on Twitter and Facebook, and stay posted for next week’s blog when we will delve into detail about some of the standout things from the conference. 

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Top 5 SEO and Accessibility Overlaps

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n1/16/13 10:34 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Did you know that guidelines and best practices for SEO and web accessibility have many overlaps, and that with a little consideration you can kill two birds with one stone? We give you our top five areas that make your website more searchable and at the same time accessible for more users.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Going for gold; developing an elite website

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n9/26/12 4:08 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Like an athlete at the Olympics, your website should be fit and free from injury. This way you can achieve the best performance and value from your website every day.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

9 Ways to Keep Your Search Rankings During a Website Redesign

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n9/12/12 4:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Getting a new website can be like walking into a minefield in terms of search engine optimization. Worst case scenario, you could lose all your search engine rankings and will have to start from scratch. Luckily, this doesn’t have to happen - as long as you do the transition the right way.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Lend the Search Engines a helping hand

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n8/15/12 4:45 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n

If Google or other search engines can’t read the content on your website, they won't show your pages in the search results.

\n
\n

When you've taken the time to produce content for your website, you probably want it to be found and read by your target audience. Since the vast majority of users use search engines when surfing the web, it's a good idea to help the search engines in easily reading your content. Therefore, it's essential that your website is 'search engine friendly' in the sense that you should make technical and structural enhancements to your website to make it easier for search engines to read.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Search Engine Optimization (SEO) and Mobile Websites

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n8/1/12 4:55 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Last week's blog post was about the need for mobile websites. And if your website isn't already mobile friendly, you're probably thinking of doing something about it. However, not all mobile websites are particularly search engine friendly, so in this blog post we will briefly present 3 options to help you make the right decisions on how to go about building your mobile website.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

On page optimization post panda: 3 tips to future-proof your website

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n7/18/12 5:24 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Google regularly updates the algorithm that calculates a page's relevance to a given search. Last year in February came the much debated panda update, which has since been updated many times, even as recently as April of this year. Having just returned from the Search Marketing Expo in London, we have lots of good ideas on how to ensure that the content on your website meets the new requirements.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Four good ideas on how to find the right keywords

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n6/20/12 10:48 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Keywords are at the very heart of search engine optimization and finding the right keywords can make or break your SEO success. It is therefore very important to find the right keywords to target. It is impossible to optimize your website for all interesting keywords, so you will want to start out with the most important ones. Here, we will give you four good ideas on how to find the right keywords.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Show me the money!

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n5/16/12 11:08 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

For most e-commerce websites it is relatively straight forward to put a monetary value on visitors, and therefore, it makes sense to put an effort into search engine optimization (SEO) to get more visitors. If you are running an information only website it might be a lot harder to find out how much a visit is worth.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

  • \nMay 2013 (3)\n
    • \n
  • \nApril 2013 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nMarch 2013 (1)\n
    • \n
  • \nFebruary 2013 (2)\n
    • \n
  • \nJanuary 2013 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nDecember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nNovember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nOctober 2012 (5)\n
    • \n
  • \nSeptember 2012 (4)\n
    • \n
  • \nAugust 2012 (5)\n
    • \n

    • \n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792136715:\n\n\n\n\n\nAdding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
    \n
  • Features
    • \n
  • Industries
    • \n
  • Knowledge
    • \n
  • About
    • \n

Siteimprove Web Governance Blog

\n

\nAdding Context To Your Web Analytics With Segmentation\n

\n

\nPosted by\nSteve Hennigs\n

\n

\n5/27/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

In the first three posts of this series we reviewed how to identify your KPIs and the merits of Event and Campaign tracking to give you the full picture of how people are arriving at, and interacting with, your website. Now it’s time to dive into two key tactics for analyzing your collected data to aid you in providing meaningful recommendations on how to improve the website going forward. Those tactics are segmentation and adding context.

\n\n

Segmentation is the practice of breaking your data down into common buckets, for example all people that arrived at your website via Facebook or all people that visited at least 3 pages.  Using segmentation allows you to target specific groups more effectively, and better allocate your marketing resources.

\n

Think about how difficult it is to look at all of the information gathered about your website at once and do anything useful with it. Pretty impossible, right? Now think about how much easier the task of deriving useful insights becomes when you can break the data down into manageable chunks that are relevant to a particular question you are trying to answer. Better? Good.

\n

There are some good rules to follow when applying segments to your data that can help you maximize your efforts.

\n

The first rule has to do with ensuring that you utilize at least one segment from each of these three categories; Acquisition, Behavior and Outcomes (Credit goes to Avinash Kaushik for these categories). Let’s define these categories and take a closer look at each.

\n

Acquisition

\n

Acquisition refers to all of the strategies you have used to attract people to your website. This includes things like SEO, email marketing, social media, etc. It’s a difficult task to determine which of these channels, and even options within these channels (which social network is right for us?!), deserves the limited resources you have in your organization.

\n

In order to fully understand and be able to apply acquisition segments, you need to make Campaign Tracking part of your digital measurement process.

\n

Behavior

\n

Behavior refers to all of the interactions that people can have while on your website, as well as the behavioral characteristics of visitors like time on site or pages per visit. This segment category is critical to understanding which particular behaviors lead people to ultimately take actions that benefits your organization.

\n

In order to fully understand and apply behavioral segments, you need to ensure you have Events set up if necessary.

\n

Outcomes

\n

Outcomes refer to actions taken by visitors on your website that benefit your business. This idea was covered in full through the first post in this series on identifying key performance indicators and micro conversions. Once those items are identified you can look at the segment of people who have completed those tasks and see if they were acquired differently or behaved differently than others.

\n

In order to fully understand and apply outcome segments, you need to ensure you have Events set up if necessary.

\n

The combination of these three segments will change how you look at your data. No longer will you simply be looking at piles of information with no idea why it is relevant. Instead, you will come out armed with information and questions that can help turn this mess of data into something useful.

\n

Say the purpose of your website is to generate leads through a contact form that you have, and you’d like to determine the most cost effective way for generating leads going forward.

\n

You’ve decided to test three different acquisition strategies over the course of the next month, which are: an email campaign, an Adwords campaign, and a Twitter campaign. At the end of the month you’ll need to apply those three Acquisition segments to your data along with the Outcomes segment of leads generated. By understanding which strategy generated the most leads, you can make better decisions on how to delegate your resources across the channels going forward.

\n

At the same time you’re also interested if there are particular behaviors on your website that lead to people filling out your form. By having the Outcomes segment activated, you can look for behavior trends like pages visited before completing the form, did people watch your most recent video before converting and other behavioral interactions like this to improve your chances for conversions going forward.

\n

To set up these segments in the Siteimprove tool you’ll need to use the Filters area. Here, you have several options on how you want to view your information. If I was interested in how people on our website behaved, and how many converted, that came from our email campaigns I would create the following filter:

\n

\n

I would now be able to look at all the information about people who arrived at the Siteimprove website by email:

\n

\n

So, I could check my Outcomes (signing up for a demo or subscribing to a newsletter) or I could look at other Behaviors (popular pages or white paper downloads). By reviewing this information, I can now understand what people who arrive at siteimprove.com by email are likely to do and then I can decide how to improve upon that based on our goals.

\n

You can see just how important it is to identify what to track on your website and ensure that you have the appropriate implementation in place if you want to get value from your data, but you can’t stop there. You also need to add Context to your data.  

\n

Context is that extra bit of information that helps the data make sense. It helps to further answer the question of “why?” when you are staring at a report. The hard part about context is that often times you won’t find it in your web analytics tool, you’ll find it when thinking about your organization as a whole.

\n

In the above screen capture, you can see the ramp up of visits to siteimprove.com via email. In looking at that picture one of the first questions I have is, “why so little traffic in April compared to May?” I’m not going to find the answer to that question in my analytics tool. I have to go talk with the Marketing Department here to find out about our emailing habits.

\n

There, I might find out that we really didn’t start doing email marketing until late March, or I may find out that we did not have Campaign Tracking appropriately set up. I may even find out that we changed the content in the emails that were being sent which led to an uptick in traffic. All of this context would be incredibly helpful to me if I were trying to analyze the effectiveness of our email campaigns in terms of our website.

\n

This is by no means easy work. It requires you to know what problem you’re trying to solve or question you’re trying to answer. Applying the appropriate segments to your data and understanding your organization well enough to find the appropriate context that will truly help the data make sense. Once you’ve gone through this process for all the questions that people are asking you about your website, you’ll be ready to put together a report that is much more than just basic data. It will be a report that adds value and contains your recommendations for action!

\n

\n \n \n

\n

 

\n

 

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n\n\n\n\n\n\n 9792139255:\n\n\n\n\n\nUsing Web Analytics To Improve Your Content\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

\n

\n
\n
\n

\nUsing Web Analytics To Improve Your Content\n

\n

\nPosted by\nMike Waterston\n

\n

\n8/5/14 11:00 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n

So. You’ve got a website and it’s super swanky, what with all the bright colors, pretty designs, and such. It’s also probably filled with content that you’ve spent hours creating, cultivating, and curating. But is that content any good? I mean really, how do you know? Of course YOU think it’s good, you wrote it. No offense, but you don’t matter. If your audience doesn’t think your content is relevant or helpful, then you’re just wasting words. But people don’t always say what they mean or mean what they say, so how can you truly tell if your content is resonating with your audience? Analytics.

\n

\n

Analytics and web content go together like metaphors and comparing things. Personally, I think this blog is radical and that every person who reads it will think the same thing, but I won’t know for sure until I see the analytics data. Your website’s analytics data will provide you with everything you need to know about your audience- who they are, how they got to your site, and what they did once they got there.

\n

Let’s take a look at some of the analytics segments that can help you improve your site’s content immediately.

\n

Traffic Sources

\n

Understanding where your website’s visitors are coming from will allow you to tailor your messaging for specific channels and decide where to focus your marketing efforts. If you’re seeing a spike in traffic from online searches for a specific keyword, don’t be afraid to give people more of what they want.

\n

In most cases, visitors aren’t reaching your website through the front door. Online searches often lead visitors to your 2nd and 3rd tier pages where the content is focused on a specific topic. This is important to keep in mind when developing page content as SEO applies to every page on your site, so be sure that every page has a clearly defined purpose.

\n

Your analytics will also show you when and where visitors are leaving your site, allowing you to identify pages that present potential roadblocks, or aren’t providing the information they need.

\n

Page Views

\n

Numbers don’t lie. They're actually brutally honest. If a page has high traffic, it’s safe to assume that the content is hitting the mark with your audience, while pages with low traffic may need some special attention.

\n

The one thing numbers don’t provide is context, so be aware of the bounce rate on pages with high traffic. A high bounce rate indicates that visitors are leaving your site without going to any additional pages. This should be concerning for pages that are intended to push visitors further into your site, but should be expected on dead end pages like Confirmation or Thank You pages.

\n

Use your analytics to help you determine if a particular page should be given a more prominent position within the site, if the content could benefit from an update, or if the page is ready to be retired.

\n

User Flow/Journey

\n

Getting visitors to your site is one thing. Getting them to stay is another story. Creating content that leads visitors deeper into your site or through the sales funnel is crucial to converting leads into sales and establishing your organization as a trusted resource.

\n

User Flow or User Journey data will allow you to see how visitors are moving around your site. For a University, an example of a user journey might look something like this:

\n

Homepage > Academics > Marketing > Courses > Course Schedule > Admissions > Undergraduate Application > Fall2014_Undergraduate_Application.PDF

\n

Take some time to determine your “ideal” user journeys. That way, you’ll be able to identify any potential weak links in the chain where users are abandoning the journey, or moving backwards. This can be an indication that the content isn’t clearly presented, or isn’t what they were looking for.

\n

Device and Operating Systems

\n

It’s important to know how people are consuming your content. Most analytics platforms will allow you to segment data based on the operating system (Windows, Mac/iOS, Android, Linux) and/or device (Desktop, Laptop, Mobile/Tablet).

\n

Knowing which device your visitors are using is an important distinction to make because content still needs to be presented differently between desktop/laptop and mobile/tablet.

\n

Desktop users are more likely to have the time and desire to read through a lengthy article or complex case study. They’re also able to consume media-rich content like embedded videos and presentations.

\n

Mobile users on the other hand are more likely to benefit from shorter content that gets straight to the point. Mobile experiences can also be hindered by pages that are jam-packed with large images and videos that require long load times.

\n

Spend some quality time with your analytics data and it will weave quite the tale about your website.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics,\nContent\n

\n

\n

\nHow Maintaining Your Website Saves Time and Headache\n

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n1/16/14 9:19 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n

“I don’t have time to quality assure my site. I’m already swamped with too many other things, and that’ll just have to wait until life settles down a bit.” Sound familiar? Time management is a daily struggle for most website managers, and all too often they deal with pressing deadlines by turning a blind eye to the quality of their website content. Unsurprisingly, this usually doesn't go well. Here are three good reasons why you actually need to keep your site the cleanest when you’re buried under a heavy workload:

\n
\n

\n
\n

1. Website content issues have terrible timing

\n

Unnoticed issues become emergencies at the worst possible times, and can force you to drop everything else you’re doing to take care of them.

\n

Let’s set the stage:  You’re working feverishly on the upcoming website redesign project due next week, and for a brief moment you actually start to see a light at the end of the tunnel. The late nights substituting caffeine for sleep are starting to create something that looks like it could satisfy every department’s fickle demands.  A few more days of this and people might actually be smiling when you launch.

\n

Then your horrible, awful phone rings.

\n

It’s the VP of something-or-other, and they’re furious at you personally because their nephew hit a broken link while trying to apply for an internship. They want the link fixed immediately, a full report on how many people the broken link affected, an office-wide email explaining the situation, and daily updates on what you’re doing to make the website error free.

\n

So much for a happy website launch.

\n

2. When it rains, it pours

\n

If the situation above reminds you of some repressed memories, you know that these kinds of things snowball. If it doesn’t, I’d like to congratulate you on your recent college graduation.

\n

After the humiliating email to the office, everyone suddenly becomes an amateur treasure hunter, trolling the website with their metal detectors for buried typos. Your inbox fills up with, “I think there should be a comma here,” and “shouldn’t this be a semicolon?”

\n

Each email saps your time because if you ignore it and someone with an acronym for a job title finds out, you’re going to be in a world of hurt. If you were able to remove your nose from the grindstone, you’d see your website redesign project collecting dust and the light at the end of the tunnel fading to black.

\n

[Whoa, that was super dramatic! There’s a light at the end of this blog - just read a little further and don’t answer your phone.]

\n

3. Stress kills

\n

Neat-o fact: stress is really bad for you.

\n

Aside from feeling really unfun, stress can cause a host of health problems, poor performance and burnout. The health problems are bad enough, but poor performance and burnout means more treasure hunters, which causes more stress. Like Lance Armstrong’s doping debacle, it’s a cyclical problem.

\n

Fortunately it’s also an entirely treatable problem, which brings us to the happy, sun-shiny light at the end of this blog:

\n

How to prevent website induced stress

\n

I know what you’re thinking: “sounds scary, but I still don’t have time to do anything more than what’s on my plate right now.”  The good news is you don’t have to!

\n

Automation and delegation are your two new best friends. You can automate the discovery of broken links, misspellings, web accessibility issues, and a bunch of other things with tools like Siteimprove, and even streamline the process for fixing them.  Once they’ve been identified, you can delegate responsibility for fixing them to the people responsible for creating them automatically.

\n

As the old saying goes, “many hands make light work of irate nepotistic vice presidents.”

\n

If this situation had involved automated discovery and delegation tools, it could have gone very differently.  Instead of getting blindsided in the 11th hour and led through the office in stocks and chains, the issue could have been caught before it became a problem, or you could have been aware of it and prepared to give an account:

\n

“Yes, unfortunately the broken link is a known issue that we’re currently working to fix. The link has been clicked a total of three times, and is currently assigned to [editor], who usually fixes them within 24 hours. I’ll contact [editor] immediately to alert them to the top priority of this issue.”

\n

It sure is bright at the end of the tunnel.

\n

\n \n \n

\n
\n
\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

Santa Isn't Real: 4 Common Website Redesign Myths

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/12/13 9:38 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Website redesigns tend to be treated as a magic cure for a poor web presence by many digital marketers today. Unfortunately for them, separating fact from fiction can be a sobering wake up call. Here are the top 4 myths surrounding website redesign projects today:

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n

5 Reasons You Should Care About Website Errors You're Not Responsible For

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n12/10/13 9:42 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

If an issue on your organization’s website doesn't fall under your area of responsibility, then it’s not your problem, right? Not so fast. Being part of a successful web team means ensuring the entire site is cohesive and error free. That means setting aside the mindset of “not my area, not my fault” and working with your teammates. Because guess what? A problem you pretend not to notice might just land in your lap later on. Here’s why you should care about mistakes in someone else’s jurisdiction. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

A New Web Governance Roadmap

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/27/13 4:46 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by Shane Diffily. The value of Web Governance is that it can deliver a minimum level of quality for both operations, and online experience. Get it right and you'll have happy users and happy staff. But no online management system ever emerges fully formed. Development, evolution and sometimes revolution are all features of a maturing Web Team. Having worked with dozens of organizations, I now visualize progress in Web Governance as a journey made up of three phases. Use the 'Web Governance Roadmap' described here to work out the distance you have covered on this journey - and what remains to be done.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

Winter Analytics Checklist for Your Website

\n

\nPosted by\nKitty Ng\n

\n

\n11/19/13 10:28 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

As the busy holiday season starts, taking a step back to evaluate your web analytics will greatly benefit your organization’s understanding of visitors’ interests, behaviors and most importantly their intentions. However, certain industries have marketing departments buried with work during the holidays, while others focus on more strategic marketing efforts for the upcoming year. Regardless of your organization’s speed of business, it is important to review web analytics before the winter to ensure you are reaching yearly website goals. Here are some starting point tips for reevaluating your web analytics: 

\n

\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n

Siteimprove Wins J. Boye Web Idol of the Year Award!

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/12/13 10:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n

Last Wednesday, November 6th, 2013, Siteimprove was honored to be able to compete in the annual J.Boye conference ‘Web Idol’ competition. Held in Aarhus, Denmark, the conference is a series of international events that aim to bring web practitioners together in an informative environment that fosters relationships and encourages knowledge sharing.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n

A Web Governance Framework That Works

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/24/13 4:43 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

The first step in changing Web Governance is often the hardest. There is ample evidence that issues with politics in many organizations have resulted in Governance systems that are extremely resistant to reform. Nevertheless, change must happen eventually. The framework outlined below provides a starting point for this conversation.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
\n
\n
\n

5 Steps to Ensure PDF Documents are Accessible for Everyone

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/15/13 3:49 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Written by David Herr. PDF content on the web continues to grow each year, despite the issues of ensuring the content is accessible to everyone. It is possible to create completely accessible PDF documents that contain all the rich content and offer the many benefits that PDF files provide. But until recently there have not been good solutions. Manually tagging PDF documents using Adobe® Acrobat Professional is not an easy process and is very prone to errors. Today I will discuss the basic requirements to ensure a PDF document is accessible and can be read using screen reader technology such as JAWS® or NVDA.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Website Accessibility Testing: How does your site look to a blind person?

\n

\nPosted by\nMarie Langhoff\n

\n

\n10/8/13 3:52 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove unveiled a new initiative that saw Jacob Nielsen, a blind user, test websites live at the Danish Digitalization Conference as part of its initiative to bring web accessibility for the disabled and handicapped to the forefront of people’s minds.

\n
\n
\n

Jacob, who works as a consultant, is an avid user of the internet and enjoys the self-sufficiency it can offer. However, being blind since he was six months old means he knows all too well how difficult it can be to surf the net if you happen to have a handicap or disability. 

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

What's up with 'not provided'?

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 3:18 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

In 2011, Google began to hide keyword data for encrypted searches, and this only applied to users who were logged into Google. They have now announced however that this will apply to all users and as such will have a significant impact. Up until now, we have been able to provide excellent insight into what keywords our customers’ users used in search engines but in the next couple of months virtually all keyword data from Google will disappear.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Celebrating 10 Years of Siteimprove Success

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n10/1/13 1:58 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Today, 1 October 2013, SaaS company Siteimprove celebrate 10 years of success since first opening in 2003. Having started from humble entrepreneurship roots, Siteimprove has grown exponentially to become a truly successful global company with more than 80 employees, with offices in five countries and customers in 11 countries.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO,\nAccessibility,\nEnterprise Search,\nWeb Governance,\nResponsibility,\nWeb Analytics\n

About Siteimprove

\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n
\n

Siteimprove Web Governance Suite: The only web governance software that helps you better manage and maintain your website through quality assurance, accessibility, web analytics, SEO, and response – all in one tool.

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n12/12/12 2:58 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As a web designer, several accessibility criteria are especially important to help you ensure as many users as possible can use your web application.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n
\n

    • \n

    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

\n
\n

Integrate Accessibility in Your Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nHelene Nørgaard Bech\n

\n

\n11/21/12 3:11 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Web accessibility isn’t something that is ensured solely through a website development project. To be successful, accessibility has to be a part of the overall web governance strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nAccessibility\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Analytics & Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nJessica O'Sullivan\n

\n

\n11/14/12 3:28 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

As defined in our previous blog post on Web Governance, among other things, about clarifying and distribute ownership and responsibility of the tasks involved in an organization's web presence. This applies of course also when it comes to web analytics, which in 2012 should be a fully integrated part of all organizations overall web strategy.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance,\nWeb Analytics\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

The Dollars and Cents of Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nDave Schneider\n

\n

\n11/6/12 11:51 AM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n
\n

One of the biggest reasons we hear people say they don’t have a solid web governance strategy is because they lack the time and money required to implement it. What they often don’t realize is that time and money are exactly what a web governance strategy saves. In this post, we’ll be presenting a few examples from several other industries who have already spent the time and money to discover the savings offered by web governance.

\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nWeb Governance\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

Web Governance from an SEO Point of View

\n

\nPosted by\nThea Straub\n

\n

\n10/31/12 3:33 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

There are a lot of similarities between Search Engine Optimization (SEO) today and the “dot-com bubble” of the 1990s: Back then people were buying websites they didn’t really understand or have a plan to use, simply because everyone else had one.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

Topics:\nSEO\n

\n
\n
\n
\n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Are you planning to launch a mobile version of your website? Here are a few ideas for the design of the search function for the mobile site.

\n
\n
\nRead More\n

\n
\n

    \n
    • \n

\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Smart phone sales are exploding, and the desire to make websites accessible to all users on mobile platforms is also increasing. I’m going to give you some tips on how to create accessible web content in the best way.

\n
\n

Roles and responsibilities in Web Governance

\n

\nPosted by\nBo Vejgaard\n

\n

\n10/10/12 3:59 PM\n

\n
\n\n
\n
    \n
  • \n\nTweet\n
    • \n
  • \n\n\n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
  • \n\n
    \n
    • \n
\n
\n\n
\n
\n\n\n\n
\n
\n
\n

Do all employees in your organization know what their role is, and what is expected of them? Do employees know who to ask questions outside their own work area? Do you know what every employee in your web team does?

\n
\n
\nRead More\n
